March 7, 1905
Orlando Fla
Dear K: --
We have moved out in the country now and it is very nice out here. We have a good many things to play with. We have a Trapese and I can hang by my knees on it and skin the cat and a lot of other things

We have a play house made of boxes and we have broken dishes in it and an old frying pan and a lot of other things. We have a ladder on the tree in front and we go out to scratched out: "edge" the end of the limbs and sit down an rock ourselves.

 Mamma says please tell your mamma to excuse her for not writing she has sore fingers     Elsie.

[1906]
Beatrice Neb Sept 31st 1906
Dear Daughter May and K 
Am yet at your uncle Docks and expect to stay the week out then go to Franks dont know how long will stay with Frank it depends on my health it not very good now Birt and Cliff are both home now Martha dont keep any girl Says cant find any Dock appears to be in fair health Hope to get better before Start on long journey home How is work getting on
Love to both Father

[1906]
CLIFFORD W. WALDEN, M.D.                                                  
CORONER OF GAGE COUNTY
AND COMMISSIONER OF INSANITY
BEATRICE, NEB.                                

                                  1906

Beatrice Neb Sept 2d 1966
Dear Son Frank am afraid will disapoint you in coming to vally center to See you Dock Says my health aint good enough for me to try it he Says it aint safe for me to travil alone and the best thing I can do is to have you meet me in Kansas City and go home with me The nearest way we can go I will pay your way home I dont know if I have quite enough with me to pay both of our fares home but have plenty at home to pay your fare back to Vally Center The fact is Frank am in rather a cerious cerous condition and and am doing this by Docks advice This is all that I feel like writing With Love Father

element_texts.text:
avon Park fla Jun 24              1915
my Dear Katharine
I want to thank you for the lovely Birthday Present you wer so thoughtful to send me its very nise & I apreciate it very much. + just the thing to eat oranges with, we mostly peel them & take the sections one by one to eat them that way. + they are very fine we have 1 tree that I saw some buds on sat that wer as large as a good sised Pin head. I heard some had trees in blosom allready. the Limes + Lemons are usually first to blosom it has been so warm all winter that the trees are coming out Early. hope thare wont be any freeze to hurt the fruit if thare isnt any sale for it this year, thare may be another year + good Prises, as the market is dead every where this year.

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.1 (Windows), datetime=2021:01:0

element_texts.text: its 67 at 10 a.m. & its cloudy & may get rain any minute. & Ime sweating like a Piper. but I expect it will get colder again in a few days. but it only lasts for a few hours & gets warm again. will send sample of my Grey dress. want you to get a dull old rose, (or coral) silk for Piping for front of waist & sleaves, get a half yard I think will be enough, then I want you to get some trimming for a hat. such as they use for covering crowns & lace for underside of Brim as well as uperside. don't get anything but the ribbon. I have just been talking with Mother & we have about desided to go to tampa soon & get a hat thare as this one isnt hardly suitable for nise to wear with my Grey Dress, but you may get me the black & white Plad ribon. about this square diagram: two lines indicating size or a black & white striped rather have the Plad. get a good quality of ribon 1 1/2 yds that that wont crack & split out in creasing it

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.1 (Windows), datetime=2021:01:0

element_texts.text: Mother says I failed to rite you & thank you for Bamby. I like it very much & I also like the story of Julia Page marrage both are good Mother has loaned Bamby to several since we finished it thank you Dearest Katharine for the Book. wish you had some more of the Oranges as thare isnt any sale for them at Present dont no what we shal do with what little we have my hens are doing prety well only 4 that lay get 2. & some days 4 Eggs. enough to Keep Mother in Eggs. & to make cake with. Made a lovely chocolate cake friday & sold it for 1.25¢ Prety good. I hope it will clear off so can go for a walk. had a nise shower & sun is trying to shine. forgot to tell you the hens have learned to fly over the wire fence & have eaten all the leaves & blosoms off my string beans so wont have any

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.1 (Windows), datetime=2021:01:0

element_texts.text: I have nasturtiums ageratum & golden casnums? in bloom in the garden & my geraniums are also blooming fine wish you had a plant of the Himilaria fern, & if I can will try & send you a Plant after a while when it gets warm, so it wont freeze. my Geraniums are budded. one very delicate Pink is out in full bloom wish you could see it I have one scarlet/salmon &/white some Double. the rest havent blosomed yet so am not sure of the colors. the sleps were sent to me from Highlands I have several ferns & 1 calla & 2 lovely begonias. I want to get one of the rex varieties. think they would do well here. I have a fern called the Baby fern its very Delicate wish you could see it I have Just 1 small root but am trying to get more by Pining down the rootlets. must ring off with Kindest regards for max. & lots of love for Dear self wish I could here you play as unclear Grandmother.

element_texts.text:
1915

Upper left margin: G.M. Has written All news, so I mail this at once Much love Mother
Avon Park Fla Dec 11
My Dear Catharine 

    I rite to let you no we sent the curtains friday  but didn't leave here til this a.m. & this will be our mail later hope they will arve [arrive] all right. am so glad I got them done before Exmas & you can get them up for the hollidays. you must get some fringe, or trimmings for the ends for a finish. I hope you will like them. I have stuff left for Pillow tops & will send you one when the rest of curtains that others want are woven as if the warp has got to b e taken out that is a part to make naroner?

element_texts.text: 2) it will be some time before you get it as some havent got rags ready to weave & it takes time to get them ready & make them smooth & eaven. now the curtains are not as long as I had planed to have them but failed to find it out til the first one was cut out then had to make the next one to match the first then od border one is a trifle longer you can use all three in the doors. or use the third for a couch cover or spread on top of bead to lie on to Protect the counterpain. we had hard work to get enough shades for the border but I hope you will like them & they will last til you can get beter ones later on.

3) as if you can get a chance to sell at a good prise then to get something you may like beter.

  while Im siting mother is baking has made a Pumpkin Pie. & a batch of molasses cookies Mrs Skinners resepie. they are fine wish you had some. we had a Jitney dance at once a week ago & I wish you & max could have been here to seene the fun of all the dansing I ever sees it took the cake I laughed til I thought id bust. & they finaly wound up with a roudy romp if they had been any whare laws & order is kept they would all have been arested. for their baystrass conduct.unclear is fine I have just finished

element_texts.text: 4) transplanting my carnations & Pansy Plants. all look fine. I set my geraniums out in the ground thinking they will do beter in the ground than in boxes and tin canns. the 4 inch Potts I like best thare is none to be had can get 7. & 12 inch but they are to large I still have four in potts yet & will leave them for the Present. Mother has Just finished scrubing the Kitchen floor & layed Papers down it it looks like chicago. use to after scrubing the fruit not picked yet & wont be til after the hollidays as the plant has shut down til then I have 2 hens that lay so we have nise eggs to use with lots of unclear for both as ever from Grandma

element_texts.text:
[[Inverted in top margin: "I guess he will be glad to see unclear unclear ]]
J.C. Apr 25

   My Dear May

yours Just rec & so glad to here from you. sorry you have had bad luck. but hope luck will turn to get beter. yes I can simpathise with you in the bath line as I had nothing in the tub line from the times I left Chicago til I got here & you can imagine how good it felt to get into a tub & have a good scrub & as you say only a spoonfull. & hard as tack at that. it has got quite warm here now Chas sayed it was 90 today. E. & I went to tampa & I got me a Pare of shoes. wer 3 dollars & a lawn? dress 30¢ black & white mostly white with a litle dot will send samp if I dont forget I guess I told you I got my spring hat 4.50¢

element_texts.text: P E. wants me to get word scratched out me a silk dress but it wears so poor. I hate to spend the money for one but the Poorest trash here all wear silk, but I had rather wear something else wish you had been in chicago would have had you got me a pare of shoes. as I was obliged to have a pare. charles went to the home & found billy Mitchel & had a long talk with him when he? left him invited him to come out & spend the day & have Dinner with us so he came out wednesday. fornoon & had Dinner & E. & I had to entertain him til about 4 P.M. he knows me but I didn't no him sayed wouldent no me if had met me on the street but expecting to see me here he naturely would no me I suspected

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.1 (Windows), datetime=2021:01:0

element_texts.text: it was him but I didnt no for sure but but asked if it was Mr Mitchel, & of course sayed yes. he seemed very glad to see me. & we invited him to come out any time he liked. expects to go to see his Son about the first of June. he is very nervious. & if a litle excited shakes a good deal. he was dressed in sitizens clothes & looked as slick as could bee. had a fresh shave & hare cut. & he made a very neat apearance. he sayed didnt like some things at this house but didnt say what the things were he didnt like. I guess he dont get on very well with his sons wife. but gets on all right with frank. we havent cleaned house yet. waiting for the Paper hanger but he get Drunk. often & cant put much dependence on him

element_texts.text: E. has cleaned the china closet & her close closet & several little things but its only the Past 5 days we havent had fire in the furnace & I told Etta  I wouldnt clean so long as had to fire the furnace as thare is more or less dust from it all the time. The cherry trees blosomed full, but not going to have many cherries not one eight of the blossoms are going to set. have some of the home Plants out on the Porch but nothing set in the ground set out some cohl rabi friday have beans, corn planted but not up yet E. is trying to fix her linan Dress over but cant fully deside how to do it well I no you will be glad to get home & have a bath scrub teeth & take nasle duche. with lots of love from all espesaly mother.

[April 1915]
Avon Park fla apr 24
My Dear May- will start this sat P.M. to finish sunday as L asked Paul to take leters to the office got yours friday afternoon, glad you reached tampa all O.K. hope you made the rest of the trip all right & they met you at the wharf, if they dident mabe some rats did, as they allways live at those Plases. nothing new has hapened since you left except something took the nest egg from the brush pile thursd night so the pullet has come back to her first nest. she was clucking a litle but it has broke her up. I finished the chicken

also red The Story of A nhin? 2 like them both Polly Anna best
Saturday morning. it was fine I tried to use the vibrater but didnt make a success of it, Paul told me he is going to get you use it on his mother, when you get home. Cora called me up friday afternoon. Mrs. E.E. Tompson was here. She answered the phone & then I went & talked to here, some man called up this Sat morning wanted to no if you were sick hadent seeme you in town for a day or two. think it was Mr. Sargent. but not sure. faile to get his name. Sunday 2 P.M.have Just finished reading Polly anna & got so interested had forgot it was so late have built

element_texts.text:
3)
a fire & trying to bake some brisket for my dinner its the first Ive done since you left, have lived on crackers & those horid cookies but concluded Ide had enough of that sort of living finished eating chicken Sat eve the wind. Still blowing from the south & its growing cloudy hope will get a shower Paul has promised to come & take my leters to the office hope you arived O.K. & having a good time leave my kindest regards. to both I haven't been out yet hope I can go this week. Leg Prety sore yet but dont worry, geting on O.K. the american has opened out this morning & its fine not so dark as I had expected its a bright pink. with lots of love Mother

element_texts.text:
[1931]
Monday a.m.
My Dear Katharine got good news. mother come home sunday afternoon & is strongly thinking of giving up the hotel & I feel glad to no she is geting sick & tired of her Job its to hard on her & we both to go back & forth & more hard on my feat & knees both as the later are so lame all the time & all the time I suffer pain, some times its harder than other times.

  I have just finished a double not stitch cap for malcomb, hope it will fit I will send with it money for ribon rosettes to go over the top of cap & ribon to run in back of shell stitch to draw up & tie as a Plane Piese to go under chin & fasten with snap or hook & eye then wont get the strings in his mouth & soil wish I could see him when you Put it on him wish I could see him any way. wanted to line the cap with net but mother objected to weare it Just so all right in warm weather

element_texts.text: had a fine rain sat that was badly needed was getting so very dry. I have some lovely nasturtiums & Pertunias & Pinks & morning glories that wer lovely not blooming so full at Present my house Plants are all looking fine. I have a double white Petunia its as prety as a carnation mother has got her leters writen & is laying down while I finish this. I have 8 hens & one has layed 7 small eggs about the sise of birds eggs. the first 2 are about the sise of quail eggs. & the last one isn't larger than a blue birds when I find the hen that layes them I take off her head not fit to live & will make a good Dinner & wish you could be here to help eat her. its cloudy today so am not washing. have you Paterns for short Baby slips & Dresses. Send one over of Each. take a snap shot of Robens when he has the cap on & sits alone with lots of love for you & R. Grandma

My Dear May: guess Tafern looks like Kafern has written all the news, so there wont be much for me to say dont no that she told you how nisely? Mrs hill is getting along some one goes in to see her everyday she can see when the bandage is removed to treat the eye. Mr Hill told her of your going away & that I. & K. wer here alone I didnt here what she sayed or thought about it but the old Gent told her so he said that I was the hole shooting match & that I was geting along fine. Well I manage to get through all right. have locked Mc-Nabb out 2 times. Sat night he played on the locker for half an hour & then Mr Hill got up & went down to let him in I couldnt

for the life of me think what all the noise was about til he got inside it woke K. & I up it went Bong. Bong. Bong. & I woke up & wondred who was amusing themselves with so much noise I couldent go to sleep come down stairs & lay on the couch & before I got settled Mr. Hill came down & settled himself down & worked on his Paper. for 2 hours I droped off to sleap. & didnt no when he went to bead. but it must have been after 1 aclock. Mr hill ask me if thare was any hurry about my going back to the flat I told him thare wasnt havent herd from Dayton yet. I guess J. C. is a friend. hope you have had good luck since you went

[from Frank Walden to his mother?] 
Highlands N. C. Sept 2 1920 Please acept congratulations for a happy Birthday. Wish you many more returns of the day. Hope you will have a nise cake & nise Dinner & spend a very pleasant day wish I could be thare to help make the day a Joyous one for you I havent forgot the one a year ago the Birthday cake I got Mrs. Lapp? to make last year for me to surprise you with I have a Present for you but its a few days late as I had forgot

element_texts.text: the time was so near at hand & it seems time goes so fast here when something going on all the time. I aught to have tended to it sooner. but I think Ime geting careless as I get older. Sunday is Mr. Durgins birthday & Mrs. D. has aranged for a carr to take him down to harbisans Plase below the mountain. & Mr. & Mrs. Shepard & myself are to go with him. down the mountain to see Mr. Harbesans orchard & whare he is building his house. by. by. lots of love from wish for you a happy mothers day.

element_texts.text:
Thursday Nov. 11 1926
My Dear Katherine,

    I have been going to write for over a week but it seems like today and it is now 4:55 P.M.
    I had a talk with the doctor at Lombard election P.M. and he said unless I took his treatment two years was as long as I had ahead of me. Well I didn't like the report but am of the opinion with propper care and eats the m.d. might have been mistaken. I am using the morning exercises as put out by the Victor Phonograph Co. and tho used only three times as have had the records only three days, seem to have even at this early date has helped so it seems anyway I am in hopes that the exercises will be helpful.
    I wanted to ask you while at Glen Ellyn more about eats. I am off the whole wheat for breakfast and eat two soft boiled eggs, 4 slices of whole wheat bread, tosted and a pint of milk. At noon a can of the soup as you fixed it, and the ballance of a pint of

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.1 (Windows), datetime=2021:01:0

element_texts.text:
of milk, for supper, grapes, (Concord) as long as they were good and have tried apples, but with poor success, they make too much gas.

   What I wished to ask about was what else to eat with the soup or what to use in its place. the grocery stores keep no fresh vegetables, and if I still eat the caned soup what else can I eat with it and the amount, or if something differant what and the amount and how prepared and time to be cooked.
    And what to eat for supper. and the amount and how prepared.
    I asked the M.D. at Lombard how much he would ask for the treatment and he said 300 to $400.00 where the price is comming from, say I decided to go. havent the slightest idea, I guess the M.D. thinks I am rich well he has another guess comming.

element_texts.text:
letter from Frank Walden
Highlands, N.Car. 7-31-1927
Dear Sisters & Bro.
There is very little news, weather nice and cool and no rain untill today for several days which made friends with everyone, business seems to hold up, and wrist watches the order of the day. I have sent for my cabinets I need them and the expense will be around 7. or $8.00.. I expect the bench will let stay for a while and other things not needed yet. Am sending all the mail I have papers and magazines also letters. I got a talking to by Mrs. Hinds for not comming to church as I did. I had a lot of work (kitchen) I have been putting off for some days so stayed at home and did it expect to eat at home in the a.m. Will send check for goods in next letter am depositing with the Highlands Bank. I hope trade will continue so that some bills up north can be gotten paid of   McKinney has not called and said if he had the Franklin account taken care of or not he told me

What shall I do, write him? Miss Pergins said she wanted to let Bernie see the views and would then return, I returned mirror & pillow, borrowed, this a.m. 7-31-'27. Work on the Golf grounds began tuesday a.m. around 20 men are at work as soon as more can be used a larger force will be employed. work started on the Manger property. How soon will you start South again and will yu come here on the way there. Love Frank

Letter to May Walden from her brother James Frank Walden, born Dec. 7, 1863 in Metamora, Ill. as were his sister & brother, Charles Willis Walden
Sunday 9/3 [1939]
Dear Sister
am attaching P.O. Order for $5.00 if repair work continues as poor as the passed two months Will have to discontinue, as I wish to buy 3 or 4 tons of coal for my room as prices will advance Oct. 1 I see no reason, some say prices on farm produce hogs are 2 to 4 a lb. cheeper corn maby cheeper, but there is a lot of last years crop a bumper crop on hand and a good crop this year. I'll admit prices are low, but what the farmers with one crop sealed and another to harvest and no place to store it. Without new cribs built. Well Hitler has began what he has wanted for some time war on Poland What the outcome will be will be time will tell. I hope Hitler and his hench men will all get killed and the German country cut up so that peace will be the order of things in Europe. France & England are to help Poland. I hope this country can be kept out of the trouble accross the sees. We helped

element_texts.text: them before but it did no good here is the reason for the trouble now England & France let Hitler gobble up what he wanted without any opposition, except their music which he paid no attention to, had armed force been used at the first dissregard to the treety signed at the conclusion of the World War, the present War by Germany or rather Hitler would not have began, this is my idea. What are the outlook on the orange crop, no accidents, and number of boxes, and probable price as soon as the oranges are ready, aend me a container to distribute to prospective buyers, it will be paid for when my order is sent in, if passable want to sell all you wish to sell. I hope you rented your rent home, I went to Roanoke and found a no good Horologist was making this place twice a week after 6 p.m. so decided for the presant not to go. buss service is poor to make it North while a trip by auto would have to be made, but finding some one to make the drive at a reasonable price may be hard to find, no the lathe mfg quit as wood lathes except home craft ones are preferable to the one I have. Love Frank

4/20 '42
Dear Sister,
Your card received this a.m. as I will have to go to Peoria to get rates, and as I have some books to take to the library the 23rd will see two roads about fare, if more than I can afford will wait untill next fall, while there will see about a clock. if I go it will be after May 1st as I will have a few house plants for someone to look after, is malt-o-meal and wheaties on sale there also have you a double boiler, also orange juice to be had. Our cold weather still hangs on, we see Frost almost every a.m. some real heavy. gardens with some things up were damaged some and fruit trees in bloom, the days are real warm and the nights should be warmer. The old Sommer's Hall has been torn down, the ground will be used by the Metamora Garrage to park cars on instead of on the streets. What kind of weather will you have after May 1st. If you have peas or string beans I wish them in milk not as I see them in water and if new potatoes the same and flap jacks, syrup of brown sugar with maple seasoningin it or maple maid a powder put up in 5 cent sacks, and biscuit with honey, if not easy bought I have both baked potatoes, corn bread, whole wheat bread, toast

element_texts.text:
nice golden brown, All the way through out browned on the outside and like raw bread inside. Also no supper, this I have not eaten for years. now don't go putting in a raft of things if I come this we can decide on then, as i have no use for a raft of food with a lot of dope on it like many think that is the kind of dope to fill up on no wonder a doctor is on the want list, good old style cooking is what more people need. I will bring a trunk will any winter clothing be needed. will bring plenty of Union suits, shirts, sox, Kerchiefs, ties &c. &c. I have washing done once a month some times longer as it is cheeper than oftner, so I have plenty of of such things. What does washing cost, by the price or otherwise none of my shirts are starched or other things, have you any peas people men or boys needing underware, sox &c &c will bring if I come such articles, if anything have forgotten mentioned it. What kind of a dentist have you I have broken tooth caused by eating pop corn is the Masonic Lodge still alive, if so, what nights do they meet. Also I.O.O. F. Lodge, what do you do for pastime, movies &c. we have none here but once in a while go while in Peoria. I guess this all for now. Love Frank
Frank wrote he might come down for a month and bother me, so I told him to come.

Metamora, Ill. 
1945?

One of my Uncle Frank's more lucid letters directed to my Mother. He was probably 82 or so when he wrote it. KKM

7/20 7.35 PM.
Dear Sister
You are going to be disapointed for a few day and maby for some time. rooms here are all taken or those not held for the High School Teachers a friend of mine hs a room in sight has seen the Lady of the place about a room in member of the person that died several days ago. was preparing food for a lot of those some of which could go home after the funeral Whell some dont they are looking for a free feed this lady and the man are Catholics this is not just this once but did at all catholic funerals a report on a room there is looked for the first of the week I hope it is good as I have a lot of work I wish done if I have to pack up and come south. I will pack all my tools and material as just a few is worse than none as to selling them the different watch schools have or will soon close for the term beginning Sept. What ever that date. All tools are high in price and many not to be had if you expect me to do watch work even for pastime a complete set of tools and I may need others there as work is different in watches of one kind may have a state law which some do compelling new commers to comply with it. I tried to buy a old school building, the father used before, a sick spell and now goes there to think of old times &c &c. I had a talk with his son about

buying it a few days ago and supposed a sale was in right as agreement with the owner of the building I still sleep in eat at one of the 2 cafe which I am tired of. As the agreement was for two or three weeks if necessary as two are gone. I wrote this person two days ago if I could get the place, as I needed a place to sleep if I had to get out, well I haven't seen him and guess he got mad at the request, well he can keep his place he may show up but dont think so. he is A.J. Mason, had nothing to speak of when he married on of the Conrad girls, We call him the conrad Millionaire. does nothing, well I havent time to tell all about him Am sending by express charges paid 15 lbs of sugar & a 1/2 gal. jar of lard. I hope all arrive in good order. do you take National Geographic if not will send as often as read to keep or give to someone that will pass it around after being read. A report on room looked for today or tomorrow. hope it is good. have a garrage in view am told it is for sale a bid is mailed this a.m. special delivery. the building needs quite a little work on it. if I get it will have a place to stay which now is an impossability. If you will send in a week or 10 days, if I get a room or the garage will stay if not will write as soon as have things packed on my way Love Frank

J.F. WALDEN
HOROLOGIST
6/8 50
Dear Sister
Am sending the works for the old wood case I did not oil the works, there is a bottle screw top in paper box and pendulum rod on wood stick the grip had seen hard luck no fault of mine, the red cap, baggage flunky at Jacksonville, Fla, when I gave the grip for him to put on train did not tell me there were two trains making Seneca S.C. I found this out when I went to get on train, the porter asked which train I wanted I told him I did not care as long as it got me where I wanted to go. Well the flunky went to the other train left the grip supposing I would get on it. the fellow that took care of the grips for the train I was on said he would get the grip as he had to find the fellow having my grip get it to me before train departure and having around 5 minutes, the grip was found by the conductor, and notice was sent to Avon Park as the mail carrier #1 had no one on his list, the letter was sent to me, I gave the agent here the letter to answer and in a week or so the bag came by express. Well the articles as far as I could call to mind were OK am having motor to electric conditions and will ship as soon as it comes a week or so. When works are replaced in case have it oiled as the oil is what I use enough to oil clock several times keep the bottle with oil in it sealed tight and in same box. Keep from frost, heat you have wont hurt it the movement is well packed and marked FRAGIL PLENTY

element_texts.text: who puts movement in care may want to clean it &c &c. give him hell. &c.&c. have him adjust hammer to gong the hammer to cup bell I test it and it if no hard to it is O.K. have him see it it is in beat so that paper or what else has to be put under one end to make it so. have him oil where wire the ball hooks on, I forgot to put it in box, goes thru a loop that opperates  [sage?] that lets the clock go. put just a drop of oil on it. it dont have to drown this place or bearings in clock. clock all tied up & marked we'll put ball in small box, already addressed to pack & mail tomorrow. The cemetary with the exceptions of [sever?] try to or do keep their lots in very good order. many put cement [erafing?] around lot may be cemetary should have a care taker to keep the weeds bushes &c &c bushes &c &c dug up. hole filled and grass seeded have those that can aford it ask for contribution in work or cash, fix the worst at a time, soon the cemetary could not a eye sore but a pleasure to look at Well there you are about cemetary, Yes you can if I locate in Highlands come a tany time be glad to see you, I wont be fixed now if I & the owner can come to decent terms, the amount is not bad 300.00 a year, terms when he wrote 150.00 now ballance Act. 1st the owner must think money grows on trees If I get amount wanted for tools & material &c &c 3000.00one half down ballance in notes bankable, you are mistaken about Leo Thuna died, I seen him yesterday looks good uses crutches to get around. at home now, said would come & see me as soon as able, going to place several sale notices hope to sell soon expect it to be a hard job Old Age woman around for one thing & another Love Frank

Typical letter from Brother Frank
J.F. WALDEN
HOROLOGIST
11/8 1950
Dear Sister
A short Line. Good Old Winter Time Snow 6 or more inches, drifted. Cold 20, twice, clear yesterday and today, melted where sun had a back stop, Mail one day late Thudsday, no buss on Wendsday as far as I know no place to go to, the Old meat marked. Thuna sold to Lumberyard can not get it, wanted all of it, as walks north of east & west road going by where we use to live only a party of walks cleaned this a.m. shall see John Sharicks Daughter Hy Marchant tomorrow, was told the Bass Lumber Yard wants to rent the East room of this house, she wants 15.00 a month, no convenience like here it has no privy as we ust to say, go to filling station about 50 or 75 feet west 30 feet south. May come south if you have some room and meat often, Little Rice had enough to last me for a long time. No cold grub, only for Breakfast, Cereal Grape Fruit, Banannas, cake of some kind Cold Water at all times any boarders, also at old house, or is the man still alive. What is fruit Oranges & Grape Fruit sell at 100 lbs over it Bushle or Bushel is same [Colloring?] up Paper tonight 11/8 '5 Peoria Journal, Up We go, Warmer Love Frank

see other side
1950
Darling Tafern:
Yours came this morning. So glad to get it as was afraid you were snow bound, or something. Armistice Day and Sunday hindered mail delivery. Have just ans'd this from Frank, and told him I'm not able to board anyone.  That I thought he had decided against Fla. and have had 5 answers from the ad. you put in the paper, and that I expect renters about Christmas time. The express on bushel of fruit is $2.13 up to Nov 15. Suppose it goes up after that date. A letter from June Johnson Smith same mail as yours. Wrote her the apt. still available and asked 2 months rent to hold the place. Also wrote the deal has not yet been completed, so she still has a chance. Told her the older boy could sleep on army cot in garage if she finds it too crowded in apt. told her Garage has laundry tubs with hot water available but not constant. Also good laundromat in town she asked about that. Saw and heard the Great Caruso twice last week Had Lena clean living and dining r. yesterday. Knee still sensitive but not bothering. Old Mr. Riffle had light heart attack last Thurs. or Friday. Been busy at many things. Interested in great news from the M.C.'s Hope to hear all about the celebration last Sunday. Love to Lucille and Nancy on their birthdays. Going to town now, nearly 5 p.m. for bread and to mail letters. Must reprove your for sending the $10.00. Wells paid rent on the 5th Thanks for everything Much love, Mother

element_texts.text:
James Frank Walden residing in Metamora, Ill. Where he was born in 1863. 
Dec, 25 '51
P.S. some or all to date of xmas cards
Dear Sister
The day after Xmas Had a surprise for dinner My next door South gave me a Xmas dinner. I already had a Batch one of chicken noodles soup, bread and drop on top Banannas & cake. It was good turkey, dressing, Potatoes with gravey, a split buttered bun, salad & preserves of some kind at 12:30 Well I eat all but the, salad, & preserves & 1/2 bun and slept well all night. She also gave me tow boxes cookies of all shape, frosting and candy, small round colored on it, also a box of peanuts, fudge and several other kinds of candy. Also Mrs. S.M. Syder thru Sim, a box of candy split dates and a small paper cup of something am sending packed good cookies & a paper cup for you to tell what it is. The day was cool & cloudy had a sprinkle of rain to freze on it so walking was Bad. cold this a.m.  now 7:56 a.m. cloudy. hope no more snow got plenty, and warmer room at 62 cut off stove at around 11 P.M. to much. so room was cold, am using lots of fuel oil. Hope you had a nice Xmas & Eats. Love Frank

[Streater, Illinois]
Minonk, Ill., Sunday 8.35 a.m. 191
Dearest Taferu?, -
Lovely mother?, robins and blue birds at 4 a.m.  Grass green and lots of mud. Had a devil of a time getting here but a rousing meeting. Sold literature $3.70 They gave me $5.00 and expenses ($4.39) Don't know whether I have to give $2.00 to State, or not. Yale told me wrong time of leaving and at first thought would not be able to get here at all. Beutall? nearly tore up the ground. Finally found I could get to Streator is crossed out La Salle or Rock Island and have 10 minutes to catch train on [[I?}.C. to Minonk, getting there at 7:30 p.m. Got through allright. I wired comrades at Minonk who were sick at my not having come at 5 as promised. Much rejoicing - whole mob at train to
We have this hotel under a long lease and are here to stay--this is our home. Special attention give to commercial men and courteous treatment to all. Good beds, good meals and good service.

meet me. They looked at me as little chickens do at a beg beetle. I asked, "Any Socialists here?" Business of much hand-shaking and congratulating. Took me straight to here -- no time to even look in a glass. Few there but in not time 75 had gathered and I sailed in. Several got up and left at intervals -- or else went out for drinks as many seemed to be coming in all the time. Have two fried eggs, bread and glass of milk after the fray. Hungry as a wolf. A comrade and his wife (not eighteen) took me to hotel. Every one in bed. Com. rang bell. Proprietor got up came to banister in nightie and asked "What's up?" Com. explained "Our lady came". Hotel Dasher
P.M. and Mrs. Burton
Minonk, Ill., ________________191
One slice crossed out half of a canned peach -- Everything very good --
I go to Streator at 9.25 and speak there this afternoon, I believe. They telephoned me to be sure and come.
I wonder how you are getting along? Did Nellie Zach? go out? She didn't say anything about it but I have a notion she would. Saw her at State Office when this storm was raging (Bentall's? storm against "dammed rot" -- "sleeping office, force" etc. He didn't blame me)
Hope the rooms are rented. I miss you, sweetheart. Wish you were here to hear the robins, etc.
Much love to you and Max
Mother.
We have this hotel under a long lease and are here to stay -- this is our home. Special attention give to commercial men and courteous treatment to all. Good beds, good meals and good service.

Hotel Dasher
P.M. and Mrs. Burton
1913
Streator
Minonk crossed out, Ill., Apl 1st 191
Dearest Taferu?, -
Had the best meeting last night that Streator has had in two years. unclear Egbert Curry -- my old school friend of Metamora, but of Streator for the last 26 years, attended and a number of her club women. Madame, crossed out "Our Wives" was a counter attraction, so many did not attend because they had theatre tickets.
Mrs. Lottie Black Meyer, my old school teacher, came and brought one of her four, crossed out three daughters with her. She told me after the lecture that she was proud of me.   Unclear (who is thoroughly bourgois) told me I put up the best argument that she had ever heard for Socialism. Many attended who were not Socialists. The Comrades secured
We have this hotel under a long lease and are here to stay -- this is our home. Special attention given to commercial men and courteous treatment to all. Good beds, good meals and good service.

pleased with my "effort" and paid me one day's wages 3.00 and expenses.
I hope to get some word from you today at Oglesby--
Mrs. Curry has four children, three daughters -- one is nineteen -- all lovely girls and mountains of flesh (every member of the family is) The boy -- 17 -- is one of those great hulks of fat that one? see and remark upon occasionally. But a fine intelligent fellow.
I have made several pleasant acquaintances, and thus far my trip is a decided success -- socially, [socialitically, crossed-out] Socialistically, and financially.
Time for me to go to bkfst.
Loads of love
Mother.

element_texts.text:
April 1913
Saturday 7 a.m.
Dearest Laferman?
So glad to get your letter yest. Am having fine time, but busy making that silk waist, etc. Got here Wed. In 10 p.m. Stayed in Oglesby Md. in order to visit the honey man (send you a gal by exp.) and a coal mine. Very interesting. Had a friend of Mrs. Huston's here for dine & info. Thurs. Yest took dinner with her at Mrs. H at Thomas's Exchange". Good din. Much good grub. Hair shampooed before dine. Several hair dressing. Last eve to High School. Lady storyteller. Slept all through it. Dead tired. This aft. I speak before Soc. women at three tomorrow I go to see Anna Maloney Cohen -- my old music teacher. Mond. I go Monticello. Hope to get letter from you there.

  Am glad the flat is rented. Who are "the Browns"? The people I thought we were going to get were the Kibles - or some such name - recommended by Miss Wheelock. Glad to have anybody tho who will pay the rent promptly. 
  Please look in my account book and find tax statement for 1913 and enclose it in your next. I will mail the money.
  What do you hear from Mrs. Monahan? Also have you heard anything from John L. Meyers, decorator who was to paint the kitchen? If not, write him again. Call up the Coles - they live on Colorado Ave The address is on that piece of paper that had all those names taken on the telephone - his office phone is Central 306. Tribune Bldg. )Frank M. Cole with "The Robert S. Denham Co") and find out if Meyers had done anything. Also ask him to with hold payments to Mrs. Monahan on the things they were going to buy from her until she pays me the rent. 
  Ask the landlord Browns to clean up the bedroom the L. had so we can get it furnished. Also to paint borders on dining room floor and finish painting the hall. This ought to be done before the phone is moved.
  Have the phone put near the library table in dining room. East side of big window - I think has more space. Write out directions and leave for phone man.
  You were very business like in your dealings with Wanzer. Hope they did as you asked. Am sure you will get lots of experience attending to things while I am away. Only don't work too hard. Get a nice suit, hat and gloves.
  You didn't mention Grandpa except when telling what cash you have on hand. Was it a good visit?
   How did you come out on the typewriting test? I dont imagine you passed it. You had better go to the girls house and get the ms. Get off at 25th st. Walk 1 blk east then turn north a few steps, then East again. It is a frightful neighborhood. They live on the top floor. Has Helen a job yet? Must stop and get ready for appt. 
 Lots of love to you and Max. Mother.

element_texts.text: Monticello, unclear 1 April 1913 Tuesday morning. Dearest Jafree, I was billed to speak here last night, but it rained and was so cold the comrades decided to put it off until tonight. Three people of one family came in and "visited" until I was nearly dead. Then when I got up stairs there was no water to wash in or to even brush my teeth. I stole down and got enough for my teeth and waited until this morning to wash my face. I find that the people away from Chicago have no conception of keeping clean. Even at Beulah's there was not hot water in the bath-room the night I came, and

I tell you kid, the working women of this movement are going to do things right along. Decatur, Apl. 11th 1913 - 
Dearest Tafern-
Reached here at eleven: yesterday morning. No one to meet me, so inquired my way and came out to comrade Deverell's - very pleasant people. He a foreman in brass works. Has a wife and three children oldest, a girl of twelve, youngest a girl of nearly three - In between a small boy. His wife had just had an attack of sickness- gall-stones - and apologized for her appearance, the house, etc. but everything was all neat and nice. One thing rejoiced me - they have bathroom in the house. at Monticello - where it poured day

Somehow it didn't seem to occur to my hostess that anybody ever wanted a drop of water. If I could only carry Lake Michigan in my grip I could get along very well. I had an attack of tonsilitis the second day I was there (brought on I think b eating some escalloped oysters that were passe) and I was cold and feverish all day. Ruth thought it was the Salvation Army man advertising a meeting at church near here. As he came nearer, we grew tense with expectation and breathless from curiosity - No - it wasn't, Yes - Yes - it was a picture of your poor deluded mother being advertised on a sign board carried by a faithful comrade who also carried his shabby dinner basket. My only thought was of sympathy for him.

Have you got the manuscript yet from Nettie Hudson? and is the house ready for the Coles? Please find out, as I promised it should be. Now I must stop - With all of my love, Mother. Be sure to put your address on the outside of every envelope. Bless you. Just got your letter. Also one from Bentall with changes in route. I correct my old one and enclose it for you. So glad you passed [?] word test - Don't try to get any news of me from the National Office - I am working for the State. Write when you can - any letter from Mother?

Riverton, Ill. Apl. 12th
Dearest Tafern, -
I reached here about ten o'clock this morning and tried to get hold of somebody to find out something as no one met me at the train and I didn't know what I was expected to do. I finally went to "the hotel" and got my mail on the way and took solid comfort in your letter and enclosures. My goodness, Tafern! how I do want to see you! But never mind - Bentall has me billed only to May 9th thus far. He sends me a new route sheet every stopping place. I will

copy the new one for you as I don't remember how the last one was. Send mail only to places marked "yes" as I find the other places usually don't take me. The parcel post package failed to reach me in time at Decatur - I stopped at the P.O. this morning and nearly missed my car in the mad rush, but no parcel was there - at least so the clerk told me, but I felt all the time that he was lying. I don't know why he should want my rubbers and sweater, but maybe he just wanted to exasperate me. I wrote the p.m. to sent it to be at Havana or Ipava. I hope to get it before summer time.

all swelled up with pride. I hope you can get matters arranged at Glen Ellyn for the Cole's. I hate to think the work will not be done in time for them. I will send Randal a money-order. It is a good thing I am earning enough to pay these bills. I sent the money for the taxes from Monticello. Fortunately the weather stays cold and rainy, so my winter hat and woollen dresses are just what I need. Tell me if you need money? I can send some from Lincoln if you do. 

    Please send my manuscript "Soc. & the Home" to Jacksonville as I am sure of that place.

  Did you keep Verne's address so you can write her?

Collinsville, Ill. 4/27/13. My darling little Airlie, - 

  So glad to get your letter yesterday afternoon! It was like the water-brook to the panting hart. I sent at once to Petersburg for the stray letter. Hope I get it. 
  The only place that is cut out of my route now is Abingdon. O! yes, Centralia, but I think I told you about that. I go to Belleville crossed out -- tomorrow Tuesday for 29-30th -- O'Fallon tomorrow. Hope to hear from you at Belleville. But be sure to allow plenty of time. Yes I got the parcel of sweater, ink &

element_texts.text:
upper right corner -- 2 
Grandmother's rubbers -- or yours -- they aren't mine -- at Jacksonville as I had to have them forwarded. Have had pretty good weather lately -- only light showers, so have not needed the rubbers. Was glad of sweater tho. The bundle was all apart when it reached Jacksonville -- the ink loose and they didn't know whether or not it was mine. But they sent it anyhow. Tafern, I am getting so tired. But I'll tough it out or die. Bentall has another date for me on May 20th at Elgin. I hope I'll get that position of Gen. Correspondent, for this work is too wearing. I undress every afternoon when possible and rest a couple of hours.

If he banks it - I'll draw a check for Spiers as soon as I hear everything is satisfactory. Find out from Doc. Saunders where the Monaghans are and write them for the rent -- or go after it. Did you get the five dollar bill I sent from Glen Carbon? I couldn't get any money order, for they hadn't any money order blanks! You must have needed the money by the time that $2

  My! how hungry you must have been that time at P.O.D.'s And how funny for Nell to go off to a neighbor's instead of staying to get supper ready!! Fancy your mother doing that! I had a letter from her when I got here. She enclosed one of her circulars.
  Open all letters that come for me and mail them in yours if they are important enough. I have not yet written to Uncle Geo. but I have so little time to write, and am so tired all the time, I can't.

air is full of the odor all the time. Also of gasoline in the pantry where most of the cooking is done. Otherwise the place is a pleasant one. I have a room to myself with a bowl and pitcher, and the usual tea cup of hard water to bathe in. Have not had a hot bath for two weeks. But I have cold ones in the mornings nearly every day.

  I suppose you are out at Mayfair today. I haven't even seen a nickle show since I left. Nothing but this steady grind of socialist speechifying and writing reports and letters. This afternoon we are to call on women to "stir them up." 
  With much, much love,
                           Mother

Dearest Tafern,

I am thinking seriously of publishing a series of sketches upon my return called "Mother in the Looking Glass".

  I went down town this morning and bought two summer union suits. They were wrapped in paper like this. (sample enclosed) in a big round bundle. I felt ashamed to be seen on the street with it, so I came back as soon as possible.
  But the union suits are all right. I put one on right away.
  There is a large cherry tree opposite my north window which is just ready to burst into blossom.
  I can hardly wait until I get to Jacksonville to hear from you. I hope you got some rent money from Mrs. Monaghan. I have not yet paid Randall, as I thought I needed the money worse than he does just now.
  I busied myself fixing the front of one of my combinations yesterday afternoon.
  I am now at the station ready to depart for Jacksonville. The old lady I staid with is very pleasant - kissed me good bye and asked me to look up one of her daughters - a demonstrator in hair goods at Hillman's - when I get back. She showed me a half of a pair of trousers which her

small brother had worn that was made out of homespun made during the war in Texas.  Left Lewistown at eleven and reached Jacksonville about three.  Am now at Comrade Walke's in Jacksonville.  Gave a lecture yesterday (Sunday) afternoon to thirty two people.  And the Edwardsville date has "fallen down" I guess as have had no word from them to come or that they are expecting me.

  I think your letter must have gone somewhere else beside Jacksonville as I did not get one from you Saturday.  Had a letter from Grandmother, Verne Sheridan, Jo and Bentall.  These are the towns I've "made" and post offices I have inquired at since leaving Lincoln.  (I skip Peoria & Metamorra)  Ipana, Lewistown and Jacksonville.  I had a p.o. notice from Decatur that mail was held there  requiring 10₵ postage, so that couldn't be first-class matter.  Please tell me if you have sent me a letter some other town that I didn't go to - I go to Glen Carbon tomorrow (22-23) and am at Collinsville 24-25-26 unless I tell you differently -

element_texts.text:
Wednesday. Glen Carbon.
Tafren dearie, Am only 16 miles from St. Louis. Had good meeting last night - all miners and their families, 100 present. Speak again tonight in same place. Rec'd ms. at Jacksonville. Many thanks. Have not had time to look it over. Did you ever write me the result of your trip to Glen Ellyn? I have never rec'd the letter if you did. Hope you got the place in shape for the Coles' before time for them to go in. Did you get any rent money from the M's? Did they stay after Apl. 1st? Am beginning to count the days when I shall be home again. It seems an eternity since I left. And am so hungry to see you.  Am in pleasant quarters, staying with miners. So glad you passed your typewriting exams so well. Send any mail to me to 230 N. Seminary St. Collinsville, before next Saturday. Oceans of love, Mother.

Belleville, Ill. Apl. 29th
O, God, Tafren dearie, if you could see your poor mudder now! I'm in a saloon (politely named the Green Tree Hotel - but where the green tree is, I don't know) but I'm not going to stay here if there is any way of getting out. I came here from O'Fallon this morning got here at eleven on the Inter-urban. There was no one around at the stopping place, but I spied a young fellow standing in front of a building and I asked him if he knew of any boy I could get to carry my suit cases to the Green Tree Hotel -where ever that was. I was glad when

Springfield, Ill. May 2nd
My dear children, -
I find from the letter which reached me yesterday that I now have two. So glad, Helen dear, that you have a job, and can be with us. Wish you might have been there all during my absence. Hope the work will prove pleasant. Sorry, Tafren dearie, that you disappointed yourself in your contraction exam. But you have done wonderfully well, and I am very proud of you. Had a big meeting last night. Celebration of the Commune

I "spoke my piece" in as loud a voice as possible, but there was so much moving around - just like the celebrations with which we are so familiar - that nobody heard anything I said. They applauded me warmly because everybody was glad it was over and they could dance. They had a good floor and I tried to dance once with Comrade Mason - one of our Socialist legislators - but something was the matter with either his feet or mine, and we talked instead, which was better anyway as I was tired to death. Had no rest at all yesterday

Dunning is the home of all the insane paupers in Cook County, so I don't see how he can live there unless he is qualified by these misfortunes that I mention. But if Auntie Belle will only die soon and mention you in her will it won't matter if he is poor. I have a lot of other letters to write, so I must stop. Only eight days more! Avon Park, Fla. 12/27/13.
Tafren darling, did I leave my rubber stamp for stamping my name on the corner of envelopes, with you? If so, please have the address changed to this place, as it looks now as though I would be here long enough to pay for having it done. Your letter of the f24rd came my way Saturday morning. I do love to get your letters Tafern! I read them over and over and they are such a joy and comfort to me. I am glad you were so nicely remembered Christmas, and with such sensible things. So glad Max gave you a substitute for the baby chain, as I did not like to see your heavy locket on the fragile little thing. When you see it on the neck of one of your offspring you will see how much more appropriate it is there. I wish I could see your new dress - won't you wear it down here? Grandmother has been sick all the week. She isn't real well yet, but is better than the first three days. After dinner she laid down for a nap, and is just dressing now. I wrote two letters this morning to John Richards, and Beulah Huston. Then I went out and trimmed a tree. It is very fascinating work and I like to do it. Only I scratch my hands and arms all up on the thorns and sharp twigs. We had a very pleasant, quiet Christmas Dinner at Mrs. Richardson's - one of our neighbors. She has a boathouse and wash-house combined. They let a pail down in the lake and dip up water for the washing. We would have gone out rowing, only there was a strong North wind that made white caps on the tiny lake (it is about 50 acres) and we didn't care to risk it. For dinner we had smothered chicken, baked Irish, and boiled several potatoes, rolls, guava jelly, salmon in little pie crusts (don't know what you call it), fruit cake (awful good), pumpkin pie, nuts, raisins, and candy - wintergreen & peppermint. 
Tafern, please see if you can find some aluminum hair pins for G.M. These will be for her birthday present - and some Euthymol and Burt's Head Wash for me. Keep track of what I owe you. Much warmer today - 72 degrees at 4 p.m. Much love to you both, Mother.

element_texts.text: Tell me what the club girls give you, and what they think of your calendar photos. I have not yet heard from Miss Wheelock - Had a card from Constance Coen, and she said she as going to write me a young novel soon. Had a card from Beulah - the first time in years that she has not sent me a present. I am glad she didn't, for I always felt so foolish to get such nice ones from her, and never return any. Had a long letter from Mrs. Marshall with news of the usual people. She asks for your address. Hers is 3751 W. 22nd St. I am interested in Ralph, the Minn. boy. Tell me how he gets on. Tell Max he had better carry the alligator letter opener in his out pocket so nobody will theif it. He needn't write especially about that. I thought he would be pleased with it. I have read a little in my new book - part of the preface to "The Doctors Dilemma" and am crazy to read more. But I have so little time to read. There are a thousand things to do all the time. There are so many things about this place that remind me of Highlands. The town is a little larger but when you go to the p.o. you have the same feeling of being the center of attraction, and you are expected to speak to everybody. It is as quiet, except when a train comes in, and getting letters is the only exciting thing that happens. When you go calling you are expected to stay three for four hours, and talk of inconsequential nothings in the way of neighborhood gossip, the neighbors chickens, and somebody's cow going to be fresh, etc. etc. And when anybody comes within a mile of the house you know they're coming here. It is splendid having all the soft water we want from our own well, and having the pump on the porch, and everything nicely screened in. You can sleep out on the porch if you want to when you come down, as it is plenty large enough. Tafren, did you ever get your magazines that you subscribed for? None has ever come here - not that I want any, but I happend to think that you said you had subscribed. Mr. Whitnall shot a rabbit the day before Christmas, and Mrs. W. brought it over. We stewed it and ate part of it for supper. Had the rest Friday noon. It was very good, tasted much like chicken breast. I wrote to Pattie the other day and sent it to her address in Los Angeles. Don't know whether it will reach her or not. The graphaphone seems to be all right again. G.M. plays it quite often. So, the funny old gentleman hasn't been here for a week & a half. He is planning to go somewhere to start up a bakery again and has Indianapolis in view. They have no heat at the hotel except little oil stoves, and they nearly froze Friday and yesterday. It's

element_texts.text:
Avon Park, Jan. 24th 1915.
My darling children,
The grapefruit tree at the corner of the garden has new growth two inches long and an orange near it is budded to blooming. I trimmed three trees last week - the first I've done this winter, though it should have been done in December. The grove should be fertilized within the next two weeks - which means that I must have the January rent from Mr. Cole. Has he returned from N.Y.? or has he committed suicide? I earned a dollar and a quarter yesterday - the first since the laundry money. One of the ladies who came to G.M.'s birthday party was a Mrs. Fairbanks from Fitchburg, Mass. she was loud in her praise of the cake I made. So the other day Mr. Fairbanks - a nice old gentleman 75 years old Dec. 12th, came over to say he had heard so much about Mother's birthday cake, that he wanted one for his birthday. That he would have had it before if he had known I baked cakes, and asked how much it would be. I told him I never baked a cake and sold it so I didn't know. But I figured the cost of materials to be 60 cents, my work and fuel to be the balance. He paid it cheerfully and is, I hope, enjoying the cake.

I was asked the other day if I would go to Sebring to take a case where the baby was two weeks old. I agreed and I was to be notified in a day or two. No notice has come, so probably the help they got temporarily stayed. 

the H.P. vaudeville performance? Am glad you enjoy Stella. With lots and lots of love, Mother.

element_texts.text: We are loaning Bambi all around the town. The old Colonel asked for it two or three weeks ago, and I promised it as soon as some others were through with it. It so happened that a relative of the Col.'s housekeeper lost her husband very suddenly last Saturday, and has gone to live in the Col.'s house with her aunt, so I carried the book over there the other day for them all to read. Your description of My Lady's Dress, with the program was almost as good as seeing it. It must have been very interesting. I notice by the Tribune that Brieux is in the city. But I presume you won't get to see him. I'm awful sorry, but I didn't see June's Cruze's picture. Was it on the colored section? I have hunted and hunted but can't find it. Think Mother must have given it away before she brought the paper home, as she gives the "funnies" to Mrs. Wray's children, and probably gave that part away also. Have you had the bal. of Dec. rent so you can get your camera and Max's skates? The ice will be all gone soon, and you won't get any skating, I'm afraid. Be sure to buy those things when you get the money. G.M. is writing to you. She uses her spoon every morning to eat her oranges. Had a long letter from Mrs. Felt last week. She speaks of being depressed much of the time, and of crying a great deal. Am afraid her nerves are in bad shape. Wish she could come down here. She proposes that we go to the Panama Expo together "to demonstrate any old thing". Did you go to

element_texts.text:
Avon Park, Fla. Feb. 5th 1915
Darling Tafern,
I write hurriedly, enclosing blank check for payment of the silk - coral color - for trimming G.M.'s dress and hat - a yard, I guess, and to get a sewing machine. Please go to The Fair an see the ones advertised in this clipping. Have Max go too, if he has the time, as he knows more about machines - not knocking Tafern darling - and get one of the Florence rotary for $9.88 if they are good. One ought to be able to pick up a good machine these hard times at a very small price. G.M. is willing to pay 10 or 12 dollars for one. Pay the freight and start it as soon as possible. We have lots of sewing on hand, and can't depend on our neighbors any more. Make out the check to cover all expenses. We are both well, but tired; G.M. from piling up stove wood, and I from running around nursing sick folks. Two of my patients have typhoid. Will write again soon. Lots of love, Mother.

[crossed out:  Chicago]

Avon Park, Apl 20th 1915
Darling Tafern,
Your letter and Doctor Leh's, the vibrator and hot water bottle, two Tribunes and Colliers besides two or three other pieces of mail were at the p.o. yesterday afternoon and I had the pleasure of bringing them all out at once along with my hand bag and new dress which was finished - oh yes, and a boquet of wistarias that Mrs. Leigh gave me.  I looked like a rural free deliverer sure enough.  thanks for all the plunder.  I send the check for whole amount including postage to Dr Leh and he can straighten it up with Max.  The water bottle is a beauty.  Never saw so nice a one.  Thank Max very much for his trouble and kindness in getting it.   I feel lke a professional now.  I sure do, as they say down here.  The electrician is at work no putting in the plugs.  The outside work was done yesterday you would laugh to see the way they do the work here -  Of course the joists and rafters all show in these houses and there is nothing but the clapboards, no laths, building paper or ceiling of any kind, so the work all shows.   I had a telephone put in last week, as I needed it when Mother was sick in bed and I couldn't leave the house, and they put a knob at the lower part of the house, wound the wire around it, carried the wire

[written in left and top margins]
The "electrician-er" (G.M's name for him) has gone back to "the plant" for more material Guess he will finish up soon now.  Thanks for the letter from Pattie.  Will write to her soon.  (Please have Max send me his formula for cold cream.  I want to use some in giving treatments such as Miss Merrifield gave me.

under the house (nothing but sand under the house) put another knob where the wire comes up to the phone nailed the phone to the clapboards, and there you are!

 It takes a little more work to put in the electric light wires as they must use some kind of insulators, but I fancy it won't take long. Now that I have the telephone it seems just as if I could call you any time, and that I ought to.
  Mother is up as usual now, but limps a good deal. She washes the dishes once in a while, waters her plants and sews or reads, but hasn't attempted to walk further than the little red hen's nest which is in a brush pile out side the yard.
  My mileage ticket expires in ten days. Dont know whether I can get it extended, or exchanged. Went to the station yesterday to see about it but the agent had gone to "the bottling works" to get a kewl (we say cool) drink - be sure you emphasize the kewl - and I couldn't wait. I always have 2 or 3 doz errands to do when I go in, and as a rule I wait until 4:30 or 5 before I go as it is so hot now in the afternoons. It was 89° Sunday and 87° yesterday, but the nights and mornings up to about eleven are delightfully cool.
  I was much interested in the movie school classes that you described and I'm sure you could do better than the pupils you watched. I don't think you would have any trouble at all in getting a position if you care to try. Have you thought of doing so?
  I have always wanted to visit the Parental School, and am glad that you went. I can see exactly how it is now from your description which is as good as going myself. The John Worthy and the schools of corrections at Geneva for girls and St. Charles for boys are also places I've always wanted to go to and the county jail and the police stations, especially the old ones on Clark Street or word lined out Desplaines -- you ought to see the latter before they are re-built.
  We were much interested

that matting from Mrs Monaghan, I think.  Shall look for the Herrick article when I get back  Have hardly seen a newspaper since I've been away.  Hope puss-cat will take kindly to Glen Ellyn - and not get lost as Apollo did.
It is very warm here.  Think I'll seek a park somewhere.  I suppose you are moving by now - Loads of love, Mother

Several people have been in here praying since I've been here, but all are gone now - Only some workmen are left who are putting in a new marble altar on the left side of the church. [[Letterhead: -- THE NEXT STEP ONE YEAR - - - 10c INSIDE CHICAGO - -15c TELEPHONE STATE HEADQUARTERS The Socialist Party of Illinois 803 W. MADISON STREET ROOM 313 GUY UNDERWOOD, ACTING STATE SEC'Y MAY WALDEN, WOMAN'S STATE CORRESPONDENT ON NATIONAL COMMITTEE: ADOLPH GERMER JOHN C. KENNEDY DUNCAN MCDONALD]]

[[In pencil in upper right margin -- [1915]]] 

crossed-out -- Chicago, Tampa, Friday 4 p.m. 
Darling Tafern, - Well, I've had the gayest, happiest time the past week of any since I left N.Y. Have been on the go most of the time. Once to John's Pass Mitchells Beach for bathing and "shelling," once to Tampa Bay for same, then up the Manatee River - a lovely little trip! - over to Passe a Grille bathing and shelling, and finally the trip back to Tampa this morning where I persuaded Mr. and Mrs. Elliott to accompany me. We went car riding all over the place then had dinner at the "Dairy Kitchen," then over to the depot to find the train had changed time and I was left by 10 minutes! So nothing to do but to stay all night. I found a cheap hotel, kept by an elderly couple and got a room for 50 cents for the night. Then we all went down to the boat and played 3 hand euchre until time for the boat to leave. I got off and waved at them until I couldn't see them any longer. Then I went to buy some ribbon I forgot to get in St. Petersburg and now I'm sitting in the big Catholic church where it is cool, to write this letter. Today when we were car riding we saw an entirely naked youngster sitting on the front steps of his home, one of a lot of little houses. His brown skin named him a Creole We went out to West Tampa and saw the largest

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.1 (Windows), datetime=2021:01:0

element_texts.text: cigar factory in the world. Its capacity is 1500 men but only 1/3 of that number are working now. We passed through Ybor (pro-Ebor) City which is really a part of Tampa, but it is made up of negroes, Creoles, Spanish, etc etc. I will enclose a map so you can see just how St. Petersburg is situated. We were on the Tampa Bay side and had to car ride to Gulf Port where we got into a small launch and rode the first trip to John's Pass. We went in bathing before dinner. Hung our clothes up to dry on the clothes line in the sun provided for that purpose, ate our lunch took down the clothes and went back to the boat landing. While waiting a boy told us there were lots of Kokan'as coquenas in the sand on the beach so we went to dig some. They are little creatures something between an oyster and a crab that live in pretty little shells less than an inch long. The shells are tinted pink, green, red, tan, gray, blue, etc. People gather them and make a broth of them, and at Passe a Grille we saw a woman with a child's shovel digging in the sand at the edge of the water. She threw the sand into a sieve, pushed the sieve into the water and let the waves wash off the sand. She said she was getting them for dinner. I asked how she fixed them, She pours boiling water over the coquenas, stews them 20 minutes, strains them, adds pepper and salt and eats the broth with a sandwich. She told me that she and a friend had a booth on the beach all winter, and made broth and sold it and sandwiches to tourists. When we came back I took a picture of The Jungle, which is a swampy looking place covered with palms, vines, etc. etc. so think one couldn't get through. The flowers here are glorious now - Bogenvilla, purple vines, cover houses and barns and porches. The oleanders are blooming, also magnolias, roses, phlox, and many flowers I don't know.

[[Letterhead: -- THE NEXT STEP ONE YEAR - - - 10c INSIDE CHICAGO - -15c TELEPHONE STATE HEADQUARTERS The Socialist Party of Illinois 803 W. MADISON STREET ROOM 313 GUY UNDERWOOD, ACTING STATE SEC'Y MAY WALDEN, WOMAN'S STATE CORRESPONDENT ON NATIONAL COMMITTEE: ADOLPH GERMER JOHN C. KENNEDY DUNCAN MCDONALD]]   [Chicago crossed out]
in the visit from the Baker's.   So, I wouldnt want to rent to them without a lease.  Hope Doc will succeed in disposing of the place to an advantage.  I thought perhaps it would be advisable to rent it first.  Then if you find you dont like Glen Ellyn as well as 4642, you could move back again.  However you know your own plans best.  all I'm anxious for is that you should live where you like it the best.

 It does me good Tafern to know that you are taking in the various lectures and interesting things and getting all kinds of useful information as you go along.  It will all be of service to you in one way or another.
  You are wise about asking the I Will ladies.  They have done very well by you and if they dont do anything I shall not feel injured.  I havent mentioned the matter to anyone here.
 I haven't taken the time to congratulate Kennedy.  I wrote Miss Murphy to find out if the Chicago edition to the American Socialist is still being printed, but no reply.  It seems impossible for me to even find that out, let alone being able to get the edition itself.  The Am. Soc. comes promptly every week, but the Chicago edition - which I asked Kennedy in Jan. to send to me, has never come.  I suppose you folks don't subscribe for it?

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.1 (Windows), datetime=2021:01:0

element_texts.text:
I am very glad that Kennedy and Rodriguez were elected.  They are men the Socialists neednt be ashamed of, and that is something that cant be said of their former alderman.

  So Pop is in a clean place at last!  Well let us be thankful.  Maybe it will have a good effect upon him.  Just notice if his ears are any cleaner, the next time you see him.  What does he say about your moving to Glen Ellyn?  I doubt if he ever goes out there to visit you.  Hope you went to see The Merchant of Venice.  Yes Mr Blake sent me his Easter card and Christmas Carol and a nice letter.  He said he had promised to go out in June or before.  I told him to be sure and go out when it was warm enough to sit out doors.
  Too bad you didn't go to see Mrs. [?] that morning.  she would have been so glad to have had you drop in for lunch I am sure.  I think you had several hats in one box on the shelf in the closet, but I dont recollect whether the panama was one of them.  Sorry I can't tell you where it is.  Have you looked in Doc's closet under the stairs?  That was a very convenient stow-a-way place.   Should like to see you in your becoming spring hat - or in anything else, or without anything else for that matter.  Yes, next winter is a long time to wait, dearie.  But think how glad we'll be when you can come!  We will keep on hoping at any rate.  "Grandma don't drink coffee any more.  It don't taste good," she says.  She drinks instant postum now.  She says she doesn't need anything that she knows of now.  Will let you know when there is anything.  She says to thank you ever so much.
  When do you take the goods and chattels out to G.E."  You ought not wait until May 1st as movers charge such an awful lot then.  Maybe you can get some one from there to come in cheaper than to get a company from the city to go out.  

With lots and lots of love to you both.  Mother

MADISON STREET ROOM 313 GUY UNDERWOOD, ACTING STATE SEC'Y MAY WALDEN, WOMAN'S STATE CORRESPONDENT ON NATIONAL COMMITTEE: ADOLPH GERMER JOHN C. KENNEDY DUNCAN MCDONALD]]   [Chicago crossed out]

Avon Park  Oct 31st 1915
My darling Tafern,

 The silk remnants came Friday night.  They are very nice, heavy silks - too good really to put in with the rest of the rags.   Grandmother has the most of the others sewed up and we are waiting for Mrs. Paber who will weave it to get her cotton weaving done so she can put in the linen warp.
  I have just finished writing my letter on "What shall we do about birth control?" and will enclose my first draft of it.  Maybe you can pick out my sentences.
  Last week I was in from Sunday evening until Friday afternoon because of a painful sore on my right heel.  I think a mosquito bit me and I scratched it and it made a sore right where the counter of my shoe rubbed it.  I went about with one foot bare or encased in a wool slipper, so of course couldn't appear in public.  One has to be very careful of their feet here as there is so much danger of hook worm.  Also sores of any kind heal so slowly here so I took extra care.  But I wrote lots of letters and read a good deal and worked at my pine needles.  The rafia you sent is just what I wanted.  I have some pink and green that I got from Sebring.  Will enclose samples and if you can get any that is prettier I will send later for some.   Did you have money enough?
  Mrs. Reeves says if you can get her 3 pairs of white and

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.1 (Windows), datetime=2021:01:0

element_texts.text:
three of black of the Burson seconds, that will be enough for the present.  You can keep enough out of the rent money to pay for them, as she didn't give me any.  She wears nines.

  Hurray for Whitmire!  I remember him well.  He is the one you refused to let help you up the steps, saying  "I don't want the king doctor to help me up the steps.  I want to get up self!"  You will find exact quotation in your diary.  This may not be quite right.
 I hope you will get along all right with the wool slippers tho I think you have started wrong.   They are knit all in one piece and you begin at the sole.  It takes 160 stitches for a slipper the size of mine.   I think if you allow 9 or ten stitches for an inch it will be about right.   You knit two plain and purl two all the way for about an inch, then you begin to narrow.  To do this you *knit two together, purl, slip one, knit one, bind* then knit plain 2 purl 2 all the way round as before until you come to that place again.   It is a good plan to mark it with a colored thread so you will not mistake your purled stitch which will be the center of the toe and goes clear to the top of the slipper.  Do you remember how to bind?  You slip off a stitch without knitting it, then knit one, then throw the slipped stitch over the knit one.  If you find you are narrowing too fast, narrow every other time around, but G.M. says they fit better to narrow off every time at first.
  There is a case of diptheria in town, pronounced so by wire from The Tampa Board of Health where the specimen was sent for culture.  Thus, in a way, I am vindicated.  Tho the Harry Crouses sent word from Tampa to his mother that he had taken all the children to the B. of H. and had them examined and the doctors said they didn't have any throat trouble, nor any hook worm.  So I don't know what the devil they have got.  Am inclined to think something lacking in the B. of H.
 Last night, being Halloween celebration, we went first to the movies which had a 5 reel (20 cents) show of Napoleon giving the principal events in his life.  It was the most
