3
tiresome and revolting thing I ever saw.  Mrs. Street's oldest son - about 20 - told the story and he has a very monotonous delivery.  Then I hate pictures of soldiers and fighting so that I was disgusted all the way through.  From the movie show we went to the skating rink where a masquerade skate was going on.  Most of the costumes were ridiculous, only one - Columbia - was pretty.  But we laughed and looked on for about half an hour, then came home at ten.  One person I wish you could have seen, "Old Dan Tucker," we call him as his name is Tucker.  He is tall and very thin, carried a little dandy cane and was unmasked.  He had on on a solemn suit of black, cut Prince Albert, and he skated in solemn ecstacy around and around never stopping once as long as we watched, and all alone.  He certainly thought he was IT.  He usually has a bid cud of tobacco in his mouth with evaporated remnants of some clinging to his bushy mustache, so you can imagine how genuinely attractive he must look.  He is the town clerk and a Mason and with the dignity of those offices he adds a roguish, sporty air which makes a comical combination.  

  The town kids had lots of fun running around the street masked, and one boy about 9 was frightening a lot of little 6 year old girls dressed in white.  He stood around the corner of the Bank building and they would creep toward him fascinated with his ugliness, then when he moved or started after them they would scream and run.
  Wish you could hear the darkeys sing this morning.  They hold their church meeting in an old dismantled planing mill not far from us, and they sing as if they would burst.  Much of it is chanting and praying then one suddenly breaks out into a song and they

all join in.  They have a very long-winded preacher who exhorts at the top of his voice.  Time for dinner.  Must stop

  Had German fried potatoes, canned salmon, canned peas, cottage cheese white b & oleo, stewed apricots and prunes and roll jelly cake (from bakery).  Then Mother brought a Japanese persimmon cut in half.  I tasted it and it puckered up my tongue.  Not quite ripe.
  Going for a walk now.
  Please send us one of those knife and scissors sharpeners if they are good.

Much love to both,  Mother

Tampa Fla.  Apl. 23d
Darling children,
Am going to St. Petersburg after all!  Had a nice letter from Mrs. Elliott asking me to come as soon as I could get ready so I wrote I'd be there Friday.  I found afterwards that you can't get to St. P. in one day from the Park, so I had to start Thursday noon.  I didn't have much to do as my new dress was at home

and Grandma sewed the tatting on it.  I have left her quite comfortable - Gave her treatments two nights with the vibrator and she thinks it helps her.  It works fine.  I used it on my back, and it rests it like everything.  Had a dirty, tiresome ride here.  Came on the local freight  as far as Haines City and there was so much switching to be done that it seemed as if we wouldn't get to H.C. on time - But we did with 20 minutes to spare.  I took a

And, of course, could not leave my room at the hotel to go out alone in the evening to see the town so much for the South and its conservative attitude towards women.  But I was tired anyway and soon went to bed.  Hope they call me soon.  I am all

The boat leaves at 7.30 and takes two hours to go across the bay - about 17 miles!  I could get to N.Y. in less time than it takes to get to St. P.  Weather is beautiful.  I anticipate a fine time!  Have my bathing suit so can go into the Gulf of Mexico.  My rhapsodies must end because my paper is used up.  Heaps of love,   Mother

STATE HEADQUARTERS The Socialist Party of Illinois 184 W. WASHINGTON STREET ROOM 505  GUY UNDERWOOD, ACTING STATE SEC'Y MAY WALDEN, STATE CORRESPONDENT    ON NATIONAL COMMITTEE: ADOLPH GERMER    JOHN C. KENNEDY   DUNCAN MCDONALD]
Rockford, Sunday morning.
Dear Children,
I am sitting out on the front porch at Mr. Hudler's where I can see lots of trees and blue sky and hear the squirrels bark and see them scamper around.   There are lots of Italians in this neighborhood, so the air is somewhat tainted with the smell of garlic or onions or both and they go by chattering like monkeys.  today is a big day for them and there is an Eyetalian band here from Chicago.

  I have canvassed diligently, but find few socialists.  All of the women will vote against the saloons, this, with the exception of a half dozen or so that I have talked with.   I have sold about 85 cents worth of literature thus far - one 25 cent book and the rest, my pamphlets, 2 for 5 cents.  so you  may know how rich I am going to be.   But I have another week, and things may be better.
  I am staying with lovely people.  The comrades pay all my carfare and other expenses, so I am not losing anything except wear and tear on clothes.  But we should worry!  Aunt Ida sent me - or her niece in Bennet, Nebraska - sent me that pair of shoes that Aunt Ida spoke about, and they just fit, so I shall

not go barefoot soon.

  Also - more encouragement - (my hands are so cold I can hardly write, we had frost here last night and night before)  Mr. Cade has decided to buy the Glen Ellyn property if we can agree to terms.  I enclose his letter which please keep for me.  If I like it in Fla. I may buy out the boys' shares of the lot and build a bungalow.
  I have had a number of interesting experiences that I can't stop to write - funny people I have met, etc.  Am going this aft. to a spiritualist meeting with Mrs. Hudler.  If anything happens, will tell you about it.
  Have you heard from Nellie [?Zet?] yet?  I wrote to her also.  Hope you both are well - and Doc also.
  After Friday address me at DeKalb as I leave here on Saturday.
  I am as well as possible and enjoying my work.  Lovely weather.  Rockford is an easy place to work in and the trees here are a joy to look at.  no bed-bugs - no cockroaches - no rent to pay - plenty to eat (I weigh 132 ½ ) and a clear conscience.  Have you heard anything from Chambers, the

element_texts.text:
photographer?  I sent him the print that had been used to make the electro from and asked him to print a dozen from it.  If you don't hear soon, please write him again.  I did not enclose the money, as I didn't know how much the second lot would be.  I will mail you a check as soon as I hear rom you about the photos.  I ordered the $8. a dozen, but they should be cheaper than that this time, I think.

  Did you get the gas bill?  How much more was it?  Let me know and I will send you my half.
  The Eyetalians are going home from church and their band is parading a few blocks away.  Here comes a funny old lady she takes steps about a foot long
  [ drawing of woman wearing a dress with a cape and hat]   This isn't an exact photograph however.   Much love, Mother.

[in left margin]  a boy has just gone by on a bicycle with squeaking [?children?] in his carrier.

Wednesday -
Darling Tairn, So glad to get your letter on Monday and was highly entertained by your account of the meeting of the I Will Club.  Your Society Notes ere very clever and you deserved all the compliments you got.  I am returning these so you can preserve them.  Do you still keep up your diary?  I hope so for many reasons I should like to have seen you in your pale blue adornments.  I know you looked swell.

  No, I didn't have to take an exam before teaching.  One of the teachers, the primary, an Illinois girl - was taken sick and went home, Friday.  On Monday

 Have been elected as Pres. of M.C. and yesterday went out and in 3 hours raised $12.50 and a promise of $5.00 more on the bal. of piano fund for the school.  Got most of it from people who had promised it, but would never pay.  It amuses me the way people open their eyes and mouths but it is all as easy as falling off a log.

THE NEXT STEP  ONE YEAR     10¢  INSIDE CHICAGO  15¢        TELEPHONE
STATE HEADQUARTERS  The Socialist Party of Illinois  803 MADISON STREET ROOM 313   [party seal]
GUY UNDERWOOD ACTING STATE SEC'Y  MAY WALDEN, WOMAN'S STATE CORRESPONDENT  
ON NATIONAL COMMITTEE  ADOLPH GERMER  JOHN C. KENNEDY  DUNCAN McDONALD     [crossed out:  Chicago]
A.P. Saturday aft. [inserted in pencil:  1915]
Darling Tafern,
Yours just at hand (via old Mr. Spink)  Sorry you didnt get the $10,000.  We'd all go to San Francisco sure if you had.  Yes, I read the solution and yours is very like it.  Am glad a working girl got it who will build a home for her parents.  

  No, Kennedy hasnt paid me yet.  I asked him if he could pay my dues for a year, and send me the Chicago edition of the Am. Soc (I am a subscriber to the nat'l edition) and he did those two things - or one of the two as the Chi. edition doesn't come with the other - yet - so he still owes me $37.75    I guess the best way to help is to collect the dues tho he takes his salary out first, of course.   The State gets 5¢ out of each 25¢.  I'd be glad to get it tho.  It's a good thing we can live cheaply here, and have plenty of fruit.  Bought 3 fish this morning for 10 cents.  Lovely fresh water fish, caught this morning in Lake Istokpoga

element_texts.text:
12 miles from here.  We have  had fine mullet also from Gulf of Mexico.  Fishing is pretty good here this winter.

  The sewing machine was delivered Monday morning in good shape.  I made a red cotton flannel night gown (see red stripe in rag rug) which I started some time ago.  And now that it is done I can't wear it until the dye is washed out of it, as it "paints" as they say down here.  Well the machine is O.K.  G.M. is making a striped gingham petticoat for herself.  We take the machine out on the porch and sew out there, as it is so much lighter, and as it is 74º it is very pleasant.  The rooster has jumped up on the gate post (about a foot & a half from the screen door) and is crowing loudly for her benefit.  she has just promised him that his head will come off tomorrow and says to him, "You don't know that, do you? else you wouldn't be feeling so gay; you'd be sayin' your prayers!
  Had a letter from Nellie Zay yesterday saying she would send me $2.00 for the crate of oranges sent her, and order two more.  Wants a few grape fruit also next time.  She enclosed one of the letters you typed for her.  It is very good.  She suggests that I type some similar about oranges, but as I can't get hold of a type writer here, I told her I could get you to do it for me.
  The Godwin cos has a little girl!
  Tafern, I got the tax statement on G.E. property a couple of weeks ago - $23.29 - and would have

paid it - only I haven't enough at present.  Of course there is no hurry.   Frequently I've not paid it until April or May - but I think you - or Max, rather - better pay it out of the Feb. rent.  I will have to use the Jan. rent for fertilizer bill - if Cole ever vomits it up.  I can't imagine him coughing up - can you?   Had to laugh over Max's visits to him.  Five times in one day is splendid.

  Frank Coomb's wife died about a year ago.  I saw Mrs. Woodruff yesterday for the first time in several weeks.  Seems she has been up to Orlando as her youngest daughter's husband ran away with his stenographer, and Mrs. W. went up to help her daughter and brought back a little 2 or 3 year old boy.  Will see her again next Tuesday evening and get the address if possible.  She thought that Mr. W. would know it.
  Mrs. Street has organized a branch of the Mother's Congress here - the 1st branch in Florida!  I am going to join next meeting.  Wonder if they have one now in Glen Ellyn?  Hope you will organize one if there isn't.  Mr. Pierce had [crossed out: one] a Parent's Club for a short time when he was principal.
  How I'd like to see those sea-pictures!  We have nothing but melodrama here, I guess?

element_texts.text:
haven't been but once this winter.  Paul - the manager, you remember, who wanted to "keep company" with me, said the other day that he would bring over some slides and let me write some pithy sentences from The Appeal to Reason and show them with the ads. I proposed the scheme and he consented readily - 

  I have canned 13 quarts of pure grape fruit juice for use next summer.  Have lots more to do, but it is such hard work to squeeze the fruit that I didn't do any today.  The skin on my hands and arms are about normal once more.  Muscles are sore.
  Shall be glad to get the last numbers of the Soc. Review.  Is Pop having a hard time making expenses these days?
  I hope you will enjoy it in G.E.  all of you - I don't want any of you to be disappointed in the place.   Has doctor Zak rented the flat?  There will be so much to do out there at first that you must be careful to not over-do.  Hope you can get some good help to clean and straighten up.  Maybe Margaret could help you.  It will be fine having your old friends near-by.
  Yes, I saw the cartoons "Cures for Spring Fever".  Very good indeed.  I can't tell you how much we both enjoy The Tribune!  If it fails to come (it doesn't often) we feel lost.
  Tafern, G. M. is sending you a rug for the bathroom in G.E.  Hope you will like it.  It will be too long for the bath room at 464 in. I think.  She sewed all the rags and had it woven.  she says that we don't have expert weavers here, but I tell her you won't know

[written in left margin]   the difference.  Mr. Spink goes Tuesday, then we will be free once more.   It is quite a task to plan a dinner every day for a Catholic diet now it is Lent.  Stacks of love to both.  Mother

[letterhead}
VILLAGE INN 
AVON PARK, FLA. 
MRS. WALDEN PROPRIETOR

1917

Friday aft.
Darling Tafern:

 Have just a few minutes until time to start supper. Seems as tho I hadn't time for anything anymore except to make toast, coffee and pancakes,

fry potatoes etc. for bkfst, roast something and myself for dinner, and fry again for supper and chase ants. The despicable ants! how can I get
rid of them? Went to the school this forenoon and acted as one of three judges in cooking contest - 5 girls, 5 prizes - two boys who tried for fun and beat the girls, 
the they were in separate relays. First girl got $5 - the fifth got $1.25  All did well. Am in
on side:  Richart paid the note to Grandmother, so we are not worrying at present moment. We "b'long to begin" tho about next October.
Very warm day times but cool nights.   Tairu, rec'd all magazines - Many thanks. Please send me some of those dried herbs, summer savory etc.

hopes of getting one of the bunch to help me. Mother got the dinner. Just had one guest besides Mrs. Pelton and Capt Rae, so got along all right. Have the
Co. Supt - now who speaks tonight at graduation exercises of 8th grade - No. H.S. grads here as have not full course. On the whole am getting on nicely and
paying expenses and slightly more - Can't tell until end of month how I shall stand.  Cora Wray's baby much improved - gaining weight, but very delicate child. O - how
I do want to go in swimming! Haven't been in since I came here - Have a bath tub tho just like yours - How is Babins? and can't you take a picture of him now?
Max, how much would you charge to print - or emboss 500 env. and sheets like this, same lettering - black ink?

 Love to all - Wants to shee you !!     Mother -

upside down: Do you want to pay expenses on another box or two of grape-fruit?

Saturday aft. 2:00 pm.

My darling child:

 The books etc. are here. They came Thursday, but as I have been getting books and pamphlets lately and having them sent to the school-house, Mrs. Woodruff, who does all of our expressing to be delivered, so they came this morning. Mother's shoes fit and so do my pumps. Both very satisfactory. Am especially please with the leather heels and good material in the pumps. But Tafern, where are my black lace oxfords, rubber heel, (nurse's shoes) $2.25?  My heart pants

after them like unto the hart after the water-brook - or maybe I should say my feet. Am really homesick and weary for black oxfords, as I have yearned unceasingly for some since the 16th of last July where I cast off my old ones thinking to get new in a day or so. And yet the day seemeth far distant. Please send them immejit? by parcel post if they are not lost or worn out. The table cloth was cut, hemmed and on the table when I came home near noon after doing numerous errands for the M.C. The napkins were cut and one ready to hem. I rejoiced at the sight of the toothbrush and paste. The apron gingham, percale, cheesecloth and lawn? are all right. I wonder why you sent me the Whitman gift book that N.F. made you a graduation present of?

The dear ol' Dix looks very familiar and I made a place a place on a shelf above our table made from a drygoods box. You see all of our things go together well, being 

the birds-of-a-feather kind of furnishings.  The first thing I did was to look up the word program, as they say progrum down here, which to me is a pronunciation an abomination in the ear of the Lord.

 Well, say, the Child Welfare Week is about over, and I am nearer alive than I thought I'd be - Tomorrow aft. a union Sunday School and day-school meeting at the school house. Had a number of nice things said about my presiding, etc. Had a considerable knock yesterday from the principal and Miss Livingston in the M.C. meeting - just to keep me from being

Told Mr. Gross he was mis-informed, etc. - that the M.C. had said nothing but for the good of the school and so on -  Another member

When she sat down another jumped up and had her say - I, not knowing that I was the sinner, invited everybody to express themselves and to get it out of their systems, and declared to everybody that I was sure I voiced the sentiments of every member of the Congress in  saying that we wanted to co-operate with the teachers for the benefit of the children and that no one had made any unjust criticism.  We adjourned shortly after, and Miss Livingston, big, black,
hairy and common, a young teacher just out of high school, descended upon me, and said she had heard what I said about her, that the young girls had come to her and told her, that her feelings were very much hurt, that she had been on duty, when I said

 The entertainment in the evening went off nicely and all seemed pleased with it. Also I had a number of compliments paid me about my presiding, my voice, carriage, etc.

I have never told these people about my experience in holding meetings, etc. but leave them to find things out gradually - or not at all. I endorse the program.

 We had a letter from Mr. Jones of Franklin enclosing one from Richart. The latter asks if Mother would be

Sunday morning. Well, I went to the p.o. this morning and found your letter and a red card so I knew from both that the shoes and paper were inside.
But  didn't ask Mrs. Reeves for them. She is a good friend of mine so I don't want to annoy her by breaking in on her Sunday rest.  I concluded I could get on one day more without the shoes, and wear my white ones this afternoon. It was 40 [degrees] this morning, but is now 72. Have just put a shortcake

Have read all morning in The Fra, which Jack subscribed to for 3 mos. for me. I find many good things in it. As he sent it to me, I send him the copies after I'm through.  This aft. at three is a union meeting of all SS schools at the school house where the pastors of the churches will give 15 minute talks to the kids, and this is the last of the Child Welfare meetings for the present, tho we're going to have a free lecture by a State Bd. of Health

I don't know how "the natives" are going to take all this stuff I am doping out to them, but if they will learn in a thousand years or so how not to have typhoid fever, I'll feel repaid - They are too darned poor to pay for being nursed, and its too much work to nurse them free, so the easiest way all round is to teach them sanitation.   I am very sorry to hear of Patty's misfortune. Hope they saved something or had insurance.  Will write to her.
I should think "Pupsie" a very good name - it is unique and familiar-sounding. What color

is she? I hope her health is sound by this time.  I think it would be great for "you all" to give dancing lessons - Should think it would be pleasant and profitable also - 
Poor little Mrs. B-!  So glad she can go with you once in awhile. Does Dr. B. seem to enjoy any prosperity now?

 I was sure N.T. would get over her "peeve" soon. I know of no state organization that is advocating the new system, but I hope she finds a job soon if she wants to go [olet?]

I'm pleased that the Catlett's like the fruit - Hope you got from them enough to pay expenses on our packages -  Please let me know what I owe you.

element_texts.text:
Sunday 4:45 a.m.
Darling Children:
I'm home again! Left the Inn last evening The O.L. and I had a difference of opinion on some subjects and neither of us would give in, so we parted good friends. She wanted me to iron out sheets that had been used and put them in again. She refused to screen in the back porch and shut out flies and mosquitoes from Rossie's room. The poor girl had to burn damp rags and make a smudge at night in order to be able to sleep at all, and she would get up mornings as tired as when she went to bed, and be all bitten up in the bargain. She wanted me to economize in every possible way, and not put so much in the dishes, etc. etc. etc. But the final act was this: when we started in, she had a lot of groceries that she bought in Dec. 1916 at Montgomery Wards that she said would save us much because the prices were lower. She continually patted herself on the back for her foresight and sagacity in getting them. Last week she called me in saying she had something to say to me that I mightn't like. She expects her daughter and a friend to spend the winter, so she wants to hoard up the vegetables to use then. As I owned half of them by reason of our partnership, I contended that she should continue to let me use them and benefit by the low prices (in which she would share, of course). But no, she said I could buy them. Friday morning I asked her for a can of salmon. She kept all the stuff at her place and doled it out as I needed it. She meekly handed out a can and said nothing. A few minutes later I told her I wanted

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.1 (Windows), datetime=2021:01:0

element_texts.text: a can of tomatoes. She snapped out "I'm not going to let you have that fruit"! "What fruit?" "That stuff that we have over there". "Oh, the vegetables". "Yes, I want to keep that." "But I have as much right to it as you have, I own half of it" "No, you don't. You didn't order it, or have anything to do with the ordering it." "But I am paying for half of it, and I have a right to use it. I want a can of tomatoes." "Well, go buy 'em then." "Well, if you prefer to keep the canned stuff rather than to keep me, I'll go". "All right." "All right, I'll leave." She went on home, and to bed. I did the upstairs work, then came down to help Rossie with the dinner. Pretty soon she asked if I got the tomatoes as she was ready for them. I said I'd get them. I carried our sheet that needed mending and call Mrs. P several times before I got an answer. She said she was lying down, undressed. I called up about the sheet. Left it and in passing through the kitchen saw the canned good on the table covered with newspapers. I took a can of tomatoes and went back. Pretty soon I heard her dubbing around and a sound of nailing up a box. At dinner she didn't eat any of the tomatoes but looked awful glum. As soon as I could get around to it I went over and said "Mrs. Pelton, I took that can of tomatoes!" She snapped, "I see you did" Then her manner changed and she asked "Well, are we going to quit, or aren't we?" "Yes, we are." "Well," more insinuatingly, "I see that you can't stand it. The work is too hard for you and you are all tired out." "I'm not nearly as tired now and I was before Rossie came." "So, but you're tired out Your nerves are unstrung, you need a rest. If you worked all summer in the heat, then in the Fall where would you be?" "I'd be a nervous wreck, I suppose." "Well, it isn't worth while. It doesn't pay. You don't have to work" - "Oh yes, I'd be obliged to do something." "Well, this is too hard for you," etc. etc. oodles of sympathy. "Well, I'll go tomorrow night." "Well, hadn't you better stay until Monday and straighten up your bills?" "I'll straighten up the bills before I go. I'll attend to everything." So I did, and I put $37 in the bank and gave her her share after taking out the inventory - $4.68. The inventory was 51 or 2 dollars, and of course I had half and paid it out of what was in the Bank, and she got half of

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.1 (Windows), datetime=2021:01:0

element_texts.text:
3
the balance. Well I'm glad I'm out of it. The work is drudgery for the most part. In fact, anybody who is there is simply Mrs. Pelton's hired girl and besides that, they have to work to keep the hotel going and get nothing for it. The place is too small to make anything on it. One has to do most of the work because you can't afford to hire, and what help one gets is inefficient because cheap. Rossie is worth more than $3 per week but she is a nervous wreck, and has more ailments than I ever heard of before in one person. She is 27 or 8 and says her best days are over! 

  How I'd love to see Babins play with the kgn balls! I enclose a dollar for you to send to The Thomas Charles Co. Chicago for a new set. Ask for 1 box No. 1. And if it weighs 1 lb. so send stamps (5 cents) to pay postage. I have shown his pictures to everybody, and Mother has now sent them to Frank to return. Mrs. Alice Fenton, whom I knew before she was married, has a baby girl just 3 days younger than Malcolm. She weighs 12 lbs. I know she doesn't begin to come up to Babins, but I love the little thing because she is so near Babin's age. She helps me to realize how big he is and how he is developing. I hope you will come down next winter and stay as long as possible. If you come about the middle or end of Jan. and stay until the middle of April you will miss the coldest weather up there and see the best of the year here - our Spring. My! I'm warm! sweating like a butcher. It was 90° after sundown last night and that is hot weather. I slept under a sheet and a blanket tho - a very thin wool one. Just been out to look at the burned trees. They look pretty bad. some g.f. like big marbles sticking on the end of bare limbs. I enclose some of the buds for you to see. No new growth has started on the scorched trees. Can hardly tell how badly they are damaged. The first fruit is as large as tennis balls.

element_texts.text: Forgot to say we each have had a nap, now ten o'clock ---- Two. o'clock. Went over to Mrs. Lewiston's, a neighbor who is soon going to Chicago. Do you want to have her come out to spend the day with you? She knows Mrs. Woodruff well and will visit her of course while North. She is English, a widow, well educated and a very picturesque talker, tho inclined to gloomy topics at times. She is a good friend of ours, tho and a thoroughly fine woman. I hope you have gone before this to call upon the Thomas' family for I believe you will enjoy them when you get acquainted. The fact that the sister shows such an interest in the baby proves to be that you would like them. What size collar does Max wear? A boarder left a nice new soiled 16 1/2 Arrow, prevailing style. If Max can wear it, will mail it. Forgot to say that I saw "The Return of Peter Grimm" at Mrs. Lewiston's and borrowed the book. Was reading Robt. Stevenson's "Inland Voyage" at the hotel. Belongs to Mrs. March. Dearie, - please mail that paper copy of Dr. Jekyl and Mr. Hyde. on shelf in my room, I believe. I had our Song Night advertised at the movie show last night. It's to be next Tuesday evening. Mr. Anderson, a [guide?] from Eagle Lake, one of the chief stockholders in the Pittsburg Development Co., gave me an immense water melon to bring home. We have been having them at the hotel, as fine as ones I ever saw or tasted. Mother said she would have had some of Babin's short dresses done but the machine has been at the hotel, and all she did was by hand, and so hot the needle stuck, etc. So very dry and hot here, gardens all burned up, fruit dropping, etc. Must go over for a swim soon. Hope you got along all right without Max. Is Ralph leaving forever? What did Grandpa Charles Kerr say about his grandchild? Shall be glad to read the American. How splendid that Babins sleeps thru from 9 until 6. Dear, dear, dear, how I should like to see him! Praise the Lord for the steam-roller. Hope the road will soon be finished. How are the Bakers? Does Babins suck his thumb at night? If so, make little bags and fasten them on. Lots of love to each of you, Mother. Praise God I'm home!

Avon Park, Feb. 20th 1916
My dear girlie:
It isn't often I find an unanswered letter from you on the pile of other letters nine days after you have written it. I am still teaching and have promised to stick by them until they can find a "regular teacher." I don't know how soon that will be. As you may suppose I get very tired, and I have a lot of home work to do, correcting papers and working out my program for the next day. Friday morning just before school was called, Mrs. 
nearly all of our navel oranges yet, but it will hardly pay to ship them at al dollar a box. The Kings I mean to sell to the commission men here. Have had an offer of $1. box but it isn't enough. How fine to have a telephone again. I couldn't do without ours.

McDonald, mother of the sick teacher, appeared upon the scene and to my utter dismay and confusion took all the books and material belonging to "Miss Katie". Of course they were hers and she had a right to them, but I didn't know that everything in that desk belonged to her and not to the school! I find that the school has no equipment except a copy of the Florida school laws, and a numeral frame, and I'm not sure that doesn't belong to Miss Katie and was forgotten! Well, I have started in to make some supplies. Mother made me 4 bean bags yesterday, I've cut some card 
Grandmother has gone to lie down, something unusual for her as it isn't 9 a.m. She has a billeous spell - She will stuff the most outrageous things into her stomach - Nothing serious. Loads of love, Mother.

those good will come soon for Mother is impatient to get the sewing done while the weather is decently cool. We have just had another cold wave - 36 the lowest. The men gathered the fruit and there were nearly 300 boxes. Of course we lost a good deal by my selling the lump last fall, and Mother speaks of it some frequently - Says it shall never happen again, and would not have been this way if she had had her say, etc. etc. - But I have forgotten the matter. It is not worth while to dwell upon it. I know others who did the same thing who have raised fruit for years - and as Mrs. Spink says, "the whole thing is a gamble anyhow."

WAITING ROOM
CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & CO.
CHICAGO
On sleeper 10.15 p.m. - Feb. 28th 1917
Went out to see Miss Ogden. Found her better than feared. She says she will come down next winter and stop at my hotel! Dayton and his wife came in after I had been there few minutes. She is a very attractive young woman and is to have her baby in May. Talked with Dayton about the N.C. property and he advises foreclosure. Said I had better stop there on my way down, which I told him was impossible. Miss Ogden said she got the announcement card of the baby's birth and is very glad for you. Wanted to know where you got the name Malcolm. Sent her love to you. Her mind seemed clearer than it was the last time I saw her. Says her 
Wonder how Ba Malcolm slept after his outing?

element_texts.text: Ky. or Tenn.  I've lived over that flight to the station several times. It is a good thing we had to hurry and there was no time for sentiment. My eyes leaked for fifteen or twenty miles. All the way in I compared baby buggies with yours and I saw none handsomer. We have just passed Dennis - wherever that is - and it is a bare, dreary little town made in a clearing of pine woods and everybody in town - thee were no women visible - was leaning up against something with his hands in his pockets! O God! the indolent South!

White-washed buildings with chimneys on the outside, second growth pine and flat land covered with water or corn stubble and last season's cotton stalks. Also we have entered the land of "tin houses". - corrugated galvanized tin. So many business houses are made of that in the South - raining slightly - Tell Max I didn't lose my umbrella. Bye bye, my darlings! Mudder an Gan Mudder

Thursday Feb. 8th 1917
Dear Brother and Sister,
xxx Friday -
Will try again. The baby boy came Thurs. Feb. 1st at 6 p.m. weighed 8 1/4 lbs. without his clothes. They named him Malcolm Charles Moore. He is a good baby and both he and K. are getting on fine. I am doing the work alone so you may know how busy I am. A letter from Mother. yesterday - is well. I enclose clipping from Metamora paper which she sent. Baby crying. Love to all May -

note in different ink:
Probably 1917 - in the spring, since "Babins" refers to our son, Malcolm, born Feb 1, 1917. Mother was cooking at an Inn in Avon Park, Florida, when this was written. A note appears, also, from my grandmother, Elizabeth Gribling Walden, born in Parrish, N.Y. Jan, 14th, 1840, then living with mother. Grandma died at age 84 in Highlands, N.C. where she had lived from 1885 to 1913. KKM
Monday 7 a.m.
Darling Children:
Your letter was so welcome! Glad you are getting on so well in every way and Babins how I'd love to have you here so we could see him! - and you of course. Can't you photograph him soon? I came home on a vacation yesterday afternoon and am going back in a few minutes. I am all tired out! Am going to give it up for I can't stand it. Mother comes over every day to help me after she gets her work done at home, but it is too much for her to do that. I may have to give 30 days notice as contract calls for, tho Mrs. Pelton knows the situation exactly. She has advertised for a cook. She goes to Tampa tomorrow to be gone a few days. She is almost sick-a-bed all the time, so we are a very interesting lot. Had two fine rains lately which have probably saved the fruit. It was dropping badly this hot dry weather. Been 96 degrees, 94 degrees, 92 degrees, etc. hot enough for anybody. Am going to have a wash lady today, so I must get back to hotel. Feel more like going to bed. Went about sun down last night, but - I'm exhausted. Dear Pupsie! How dreadful to be not wanted. And she is such a well-meaning, good natured pup. You had not mentioned her before since I left, until your last letter. I couldn't possibly take her. Her coat would harbor all

Sometime ago had a newspaper from Paris, Ill, filled with ads of a gold mine stock concern, with the name of Geo. E. Bowen, Vice-President of the company! No mention made of any President. VILLAGE INN
AVON PARK, FLA.
MRS. M. WALDEN
PROPRIETRESS
7-9-17
Sunday morning
Darling Tafern:
I notice by the Leader (probably the Milwaukee Leader, a socialist publication. KKM) that the Int. Soc. Rev. for July has been suppressed. I have been wondering why I didn't get my July copy. (Did I tell you I sent in a sub-card and had it sent to the Village Inn?) Can't you get a copy from Papa, then send it on to me? Now that I have the time I read all of my Soc. periodicals from beginning to end. Had a nice letter from Marie Roever (my ship-mate) yesterday. She is now in New London, Conn. waitress in the Hotel Griswold. Says there is much hatred toward the Germans from the other "help" and one girl remarked that she thought it very unfair that they still employ those Germans, and that she knows a girl who was chased out of 7 positions in N.Y. city for being German and that she

wished all Germans would be treated the same. Then she adds, "Well, I thought - you poor fish." She doesn't think there will be a Revolution in Germany "We Germans do agree with the methods of our government and believe me a Republic would not improve conditions in Germany. The Germans are a different tribe of people and always choose one as leader and loved him; if it should come to a Revolution here it will be soley an uprising against the pressure of the Capitalists and most likely will come. I rejoice myself over the Russians and only do hope it will be lasting. I think that America will come to a halt after her first heavy losses, for she will have to suffer them and all her men won't be able to break the Western line. Switzerland has openly declared that her people will rather live on roots and slowly starve before she will become unneutral for America's purpose. I think they will have to make terms with Germany after

awhile and recognize their mistake for Germany's Government is that of a highly civilized tribe." It is very interesting to me to get her viewpoint. Belonging as she does to the middle-class which always supports a government, she is loyal to the Keiser and not at all informed as to the movement of the minor Soc. party in Germany. There is an interesting article in the Appeal (July 7) (KKM- Appeal to Reason, published in Girard, Kansas) on the possibility of a Revolution in Germany. To my mind that is the only think that will end the War. G. Bernhard Shaw wrote an article at the beginning of the War that was headed, "If we can't beat Potsdam we must depend upon an American Alliance." See how fore-sighted he is! Last Friday aft. there was a meeting of the Mothers' Congress {parentheses and initials inserted in a different hand, in different ink}  (later to become the PTA  KKM) which was almost torn asunder by a discussion of topics akin to the War. She considered that work very necessary, etc. etc. After more discussion pro and con we tried to get a vote on the program proposed. The Birth Control topic was timidly voted down, the Maternal Mortality topic could get only 1 vote in favor of it - mine - and none against it - so it was dropped and the question of the Baby Parade, which couldn't get a vote either, was postponed until the next meeting. I had planned to have an all day picnic at Mrs Fairbanks home on July 20th for the M.C. as Mrs. F. (now in Fitchburg) has written me to get the key to her house, to open it up and use it "as often as possible", so I at once jumped at the chance to have a meeting there, have everybody bring their bathing suits and have a good time. Thus harmony was restored, and Mrs. Swearingen put herself down for potato salad for the picnic, tho she said she couldn't be there for dinner, as Mamma wasn't very well and Bob wasn't at all well and he wanted his dinner at 12 o'clock and he wanted it hot. She left as soon as refreshments were served and everybody was glad to see her go, tho her resignation wasn't acted upon. I noticed that on the way home, no one in our group defended her actions tho some supported in meeting her conservative ideas. I forgot to say that Mrs. S. can't knit, sew, or crochet to save her life. I've often heard her say that she would give anything if she could use her fingers. And her mother, who used to have a beautiful soprano voice, was so highly educated in music that she can't make a cup of tea or a piece of toast. Mrs. S. herself says that, "It's pitiful to be so helpless." The town

is also torn up over the formation of a Red Cross chapter. Sebring people came up and organized a mass meeting here and the town raised over five hundred dollars. Sebring raised something over four hundred, the surrounding settlements nearly six hundred, so Sebring sent the word on to Washington that it and surrounding territory had raised $1500. and it wanted the R.C. chapter located there. Mrs. S. was greatly excited over the affair and wanted the M.C. support to deny Sebrings' and get the R.C. chapter here in A.P. "For if we don't get the chapter here, it will mean that Sebring will fight for county division and will get the county seat for herself. And if we don't fight for it we lose the county seat right now!" I very quietly said, "I don't see how you can help yourself now: the Sebring people had this all planned before they called you up Sunday morning, and you fell for it like a lot of suckers and let them organize you, so there is

I sent to Washington and got all their pamphlets and read them thoroughly, so I was prepared to intelligently oppose the thing, while Mrs. S. I find, know almost nothing about it. But she can't qualify, and I don't believe Mrs. Lauder can tho she is trying to. 10 pages, and I haven't mentioned Babins! Don't let him have any paper to rattle or tear so he will always respect his books and your newspapers. So glad you called on the Thomas family and enjoyed it so much. I'm sure you will find them good friends and nice people. The tatting hasn't progressed this week. Hope I'll get the dress done before it's time to put him into overalls! Yes, you were in highest spirits when you had succeeded in messing yourself all up, and I find that that is the rule in Babydom. They all are. You have heard me mention Mrs. Starkey? She used to go swimming with me. I went to see her Friday after the M.C. meeting. She was unable to come, and I find that she has fibroid tumor and will probably be operated on. Will go to Indianapolis soon, I think - their home town is Terre Haute. She has

Have written Nellie Day about her remedies for Mrs. Starkey - tho I think she is too far along for absorption. I talked with her two years ago and advised an operation then, and she tells me she was examined before they came down here 6 yrs ago, and the doctor advised an operation then! I can only hope she will pull thru. They have two fine boys 9 and 14, and they are such a happy, united family. They have a good home here besides a homestead which they lately bought the right in, and also a home in Terre Haute. Seems a pity that they didn't put a little into her health instead of so much into real estate. Oceans of love, Mother.

Avon Park, Fla. Nov. 30, 1926
Darling Tafern:
We have just had a soul-stirring hunt for an oil check which came yesterday. I handed it to Uncle when we got home from town so he could open it and gloat over it while Mother and I went to call on Mrs. Allan Woodruff. Today I asked him where it was so I could enter it. He said he put it in a pigeon hole in my desk. Then he pulled one out of his pocket that came the day before. As I had given him both of them at the same time we, neither of us, could understand why he had one and not the other. Hence the grand search with excitement waxing higher and oaths hotter every minute on the part of our aged relative.

element_texts.text: I took out some stamped envelopes for one to address to you - and behold the lost oil-check at the bottom of the pile. Great rejoicing! Saturday afternoon Elmore Wray with Cora and the two younger ones, came over with a wonderful radio set which he installed" for me to play with."  Hoping thereby to make a sale of it to our wealthy relative. Elmore assured him that it would cure the deafness that has bothered him for years. But there was so much static Sunday night that we couldn't get the announcements, and yesterday morning he said he thought the radio was a fizzle. Last night tho between 8:30 and 9:30 the PIttsburgh Post gave concert consisting of selections from old operas that I got no end of enjoyment from. The first was from the MIkado - the first light opera I ever heard - then one from an opera in which Anna Held was the star which I

heard with you and Papa - the last one I ever went to with you both. Then Wednesday morning, I don't know what. The Kenneys - the baby sleeping quietly on the bed - Mr. Miller, Cora and Elenore were here last evening. We heard Pinafore given from Jax by Choral Society. They did very well, but slightly amateurish. Heard the dinner program from PIttsburgh from 6 to 7. Am sure Uncle will not keep the radio. Says there is too much g-r-r-r-r. But last night it was fine. I heard the lecture-recital on the development of music last evening after the others had gone to bed. Enjoyed it very much. Also at twelve got up and turned it on for a few notes to see what was going on - a negro song, so I shut it off. This set is a wonder, The tone is so rich and mellow and everything as clear as if in the room when no static.

element_texts.text: am crazy to have it but -- $250.00 and Uncle has to give money to Minnie to buy back the farm. Must hurry as have to go to town and this aft. to library to work, rebinding old books. Such a job. Wish I could hear your play. I think the Black Pirate was here about two months ago. Wanted to see it, but didn't. Yes the fire place is dandy. Burns without smoking and heats fine. Have used it only 3 or 4 times as weather so mild. Wish I could help on those wool comforters. So glad Malcolm is interested in his music. He will get so much satisfaction out of it if he keeps on. I meant those BVD's for Malcolm anyway. Think he can wear them next summer.

Oh Tafern darling. Don't talk about Christmas presents. Get me a new nail file. I broke mine the other day. No set, just the file. And nothing else. And nothing to Uncle. It puts him in misery to get things from anybody that he thinks needs the money for something else. Send some pretty Kimona cloth for Gm. and I will make it up. Something that won't fade and like light-weight outing flannel, only figured - pink and  green gray or blue and green grey flowers and leaves. She gave hers to the refugees. We caught two of Brendles pullets that have lived off of us since they were hatched. Had one for Thgsvg and Mrs. Spink took the other at $1.25. Also our tenants gave us some barbecued pig. Very good. out in front of lot next east of the old house. Sat up until 4 a.m. cooking it. How is Papa? Any signs of senility yet? Hope he doesn't put things away and forget where they are! Must stop. Oceans of love, Mother. Uncle is awful stingy with me, wants to pare down expenses all the time, so I don't know that I'll be able to send any Xmas except box of fruit. Have earned a little baking bread that he doesn't know about, but want to send that to Frank. 
Alice is better. Her sister-in-law here now for short time from Wisc.
